paragraphs.content: Ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ τὰ μὲν ζώων σώματα κέκραται, καὶ ὡς οὐκ ἴση πάντων ἐστὶν ἐν τῇ κράσει μοῖρα, παλαιοῖς ἀνδράσιν ἱκανῶς ἀποδέδεικται, φιλοσόφων τε καὶ ἰατρῶν τοῖς ἀρίστοις· εἴρηται δὲ καὶ πρὸς ἡμῶν ὑπὲρ αὐτῶν τὰ εἰκότα δι’ ἑτέρου γράμματος, ἐν ᾧ περὶ τῶν καθ’ Ἱπποκράτην στοιχείων ἐσκοπούμεθα. νυνὶ δὲ, ὅπερ ἐστὶν ἐφεξῆς ἐκείνῳ, τῶν κράσεων ἁπάσας ἐξευρεῖν τὰς διαφορὰς, ὁπόσαι τέ εἰσι καὶ ὁποῖαι, κατ’ εἴδη τε καὶ γένη διαιρούμενος, ἐν τῷδε τῷ γράμματι δίειμι, τὴν ἀρχὴν ἀπὸ τῆς τῶν ὀνομάτων ἐξηγήσεως ποιησάμενος. ἐπειδὰν μὲν γὰρ ἐκ θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ κεκρᾶσθαι λέγωσι τὰ σώματα, τῶν ἄκρως τοιούτων ἀκούειν φασὶ χρῆναι, τοῦτ’ ἔστι τῶν στοιχείων αὐτῶν, ἀέρος, καὶ πυρὸς, καὶ ὕδατος, καὶ γῆς. ἐπειδὰν δὲ ζῶον, ἢ φυτὸν, ἢ θερμὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ξηρὸν, ἢ ὑγρὸν, οὐκέθ’ ὡσαύτως. οὐδὲ γὰρ δύνασθαι ζῶον οὐδὲν οὔτ’ ἄκρως θερμὸν ὑπάρχειν, ὡς πῦρ, οὔτ’ ἄκροις ὑγρὸν, ὡς ὕδωρ· ὡσαύτως δὲ οὐδὲ ψυχρὸν ἢ ξηρὸν ἐσχάτως· ἀλλ’ ἀπὸ τοῦ πλεονεκτοῦντος ἐν τῇ κράσει γίνεσθαι τὰς προσηγορίας, ὑγρὸν μὲν καλούντων ἡμῶν, ἐν ᾧ πλείονος ὑγρότητός ἐστι μοῖρα, ξηρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ ξηρότητος· οὕτω δὲ καὶ θερμὸν μὲν, ἐν ᾧ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖ, ψυχρὸν δὲ, ἐν ᾧ τὸ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ. αὕτη μὲν τῶν ὀνομάτων χρῆσις.
paragraphs.openai_translation:
That the bodies of animals are compounded from hot, cold, dry, and wet, and that the share of each in the mixture is not equal, has been sufficiently demonstrated by the ancients, the best of both philosophers and physicians. And I too have set forth the probable considerations about these matters in another treatise, in which I examined the elements according to Hippocrates. Now, as a sequel to that, I shall in this treatise go through and discover all the differences of mixtures [krasis], how many there are and of what sorts, dividing them by species and by genera, beginning with an explanation of the terms.

For when they say that bodies are mixed from hot, cold, dry, and wet, they say one must understand these in their extreme forms—that is, the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But when it is a matter of an animal, or a plant, or of something being called hot, cold, dry, or wet, it is not in the same way. For no animal can be absolutely hot, like fire, nor absolutely wet, like water; and likewise neither utterly cold nor utterly dry. Rather, the appellations arise from what predominates in the mixture: we call “wet” that in which there is a larger share of wetness, and “dry” that in which there is dryness; and so too “hot” where the hot prevails over the cold, and “cold” where the cold prevails over the hot. Such is the usage of the terms.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
**Translation:**

That the bodies of living beings are composed of hot and cold and dry and moist, and that the share of all these in the mixture is not equal, has been sufficiently demonstrated by the ancients, by the best of both philosophers and physicians. What is reasonable concerning these matters has also been stated by us in another treatise, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now, what follows upon that work—to discover all the differences of the mixtures [temperaments], how many they are and of what kind, dividing them according to species and genera—I shall go through in this treatise, making my beginning from the explanation of the terms.

For when they say that bodies are mixed from hot and cold and dry and moist, they assert that one must understand these as the extreme forms of such qualities, that is, the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But when they speak of an animal or plant as hot or cold or dry or moist, it is no longer in the same way. For no living being can be either extremely hot, like fire, or extremely moist, like water; and likewise neither extremely cold nor dry. Rather, the designations come from what predominates in the mixture, as we call "moist" that in which there is a greater share of moisture, and "dry" that in which there is more dryness; and thus also "hot" that in which the hot exceeds the cold, and "cold" that in which the cold exceeds the hot. This, then, is the usage of the terms.
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
That the bodies of living things are compounded, then, from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the wet, and that the share of each is not equal in the mixture [κράσις], has been sufficiently demonstrated by the men of old—by the best among both philosophers and physicians. The appropriate matters concerning these things have also been stated by us in another treatise, in which we examined the elements according to Hippocrates. But now, in this treatise, as the next topic in sequence to that one, I shall proceed to discover all the differences of the mixtures [κράσεις]—how many and of what sort they are—dividing them by species and genera, making my start from an explanation of the terms.

For whenever they say that bodies are compounded from the hot, the cold, the dry, and the wet, they mean that one must understand this to refer to these qualities in their absolute form, that is, to the elements themselves: air, fire, water, and earth. But when they call an animal or a plant hot, or cold, or dry, or wet, it is no longer in the same way. For no animal can exist that is either hot in the absolute sense, like fire, or wet in the absolute sense, like water; and likewise, neither can it be cold or dry to the utmost degree. Rather, the designations arise from the quality that predominates in the mixture, so that we call a thing ‘wet’ in which there is a greater share of wetness, and ‘dry’ in which there is a greater share of dryness. And so too, a thing is called ‘hot’ in which the hot predominates over the cold, and ‘cold’ in which the cold predominates over the hot. This, then, is the use of these terms.

paragraphs.content: Ὥρα δ’ ἂν εἴη λέγειν ἤδη καὶ περὶ τῶν κράσεων αὐτῶν. ἡ μὲν δὴ πλείστη δόξα τῶν ἐπιφανεστάτων ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων, ὑγρὰν εἶναι καὶ θερμὴν κρᾶσιν, ἑτέραν τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ ψυχρᾶς, καὶ τρίτην ἐπὶ ταύταις τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ ψυχρὰν, ἑτέραν τῆς ξηρᾶς τε ἅμα καὶ θερμῆς. ἔνιοι δ’ ἐξ αὐτῶν ὑγρὰν μέν τινα καὶ ψυχρὰν ἅμα κρᾶσιν ὑπάρχειν φασὶ, θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν· οὐ μὴν οὔτε τὴν ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν, οὔτε τὴν ψυχρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηράν. οὐ γὰρ ἐγχωρεῖν οὔθ’ ὑγρότητα πλεονεκτούσῃ θερμότητι συνδραμεῖν, οὔτε ξηρότητα ψυχρότητι. δαπανᾶσθαι μὲν γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος τὴν ὑγρότητα, καὶ οὕτως θερμὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν γίνεσθαι τὸ σῶμα, μένειν δὲ ἄπεπτόν τε καὶ ἀκατέργαστον, ἐν οἶς ἂν σώμασιν ἀῤῥωστῇ τὸ θερμὸν, ὥστ’ ἀναγκαῖον εἶναι, θερμότητος μὲν ἐπικρατούσης, ἕπεσθαι ξηρότητα, ψυχρότητος δὲ πλεονεκτούσης, ἀκολουθεῖν ὑγρότητα. οὗτοι μὲν οὖν κατὰ τάδε πεπείκασι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς, ὡς δύο εἰσὶ πᾶσαι τῶν κράσεων αἱ διαφοραί. ὅσοι δὲ τέτταρας εἶναι νομίζουσι, διχῶς τούτοις ἀντιλέγουσιν· ἔνιοι μὲν εὐθὺς τὸ πρῶτον ἀξίωμα μὴ συγχωροῦντες, ὡς ἐξικμάζεσθαι τὴν ὑγρότητα πρὸς τοῦ θερμοῦ κρατοῦντος ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν· ἔνιοι δὲ τοῦτο μὲν συγχωροῦσιν, ἀμφισβητοῦσι δὲ ἑτέρως. οἱ μὲν δὴ πρῶτοι τοῦ θερμοῦ μὲν ἔργον εἶναί φασι τὸ θερμαίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ψυχροῦ τὸ ψύχειν, τοῦ ξηροῦ δ’ αὖ τὸ ξηραίνειν, ὥσπερ καὶ τοῦ ὑγροῦ τὸ ὑγραίνειν. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο, ὅσα μὲν σώματα θερμὰ τὴν φύσιν ἐστὶν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰ, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, ᾗ μὲν θερμὰ, θερμαίνει, ᾗ δὲ ξηρὰ, ξηραίνει. ὅσα δ’ ὑγρὰ καὶ θερμὰ, καθάπερ ὕδωρ θερμὸν, ὑγραίνειν ταῦτα καὶ θερμαίνειν πέφυκεν ἀεὶ, ἓν ἑκατέρας κᾀνταῦθα ποιότητος ἔργον ἐχούσης ἀχώριστον. οὐκ οὖν συγχωροῦσιν, εἴ τι θερμαῖνόν ἐστιν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ξηραίνειν· ἀλλ’ εἰ μὲν ὑγρότης προσείη τῇ θερμότητι, θερμαίνειν ἅμα καὶ ὑγραίνειν, ὥσπερ τὰ λουτρὰ τῶν γλυκέων ὑδάτων· εἰ δ’, ὥσπερ θερμὸν, οὕτω καὶ ξηρὸν εἴη, καθάπερ τὸ πῦρ, οὐ θερμαίνειν μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ ξηραίνειν εὐθὺς, οὐκ ἐκ τῆς θερμότητος τοῦτο λαβὸν, ἀλλ’ ἐκ τῆς συνούσης αὐτῇ ξηρότητος. ὑπομιμνήσκουσι δ’ ἐνταῦθα τῶν ἐν ἡλίῳ θερινῷ διατριψάντων ἐπιπλέον, εἶθ’, ὡς εἰκὸς, αὐανθέντων, ὅλον τε τὸ σῶμα καὶ ξηρὸν καὶ αὐχμηρὸν ἐχόντων, καὶ διψώντων οὐκ ἀνεκτῶς. ἴασιν γὰρ αὐτοῖς εἶναί φασιν ἑτοίμην τε καὶ ῥᾴστην, οὐκ εἰ πίοιεν μόνον, ἀλλὰ εἰ καὶ λούσαιντο θερμοῖς ὕδασι καὶ γλυκέσιν, ὡς τῆς ὑγρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ ψυχρότητος, εἴτε μετὰ θερμότητος εἴη, τὸ ἑαυτῆς δρᾷν δυναμένης, ὑγραίνειν γὰρ τὰ πλησιάζοντα. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν λόγον φασὶ καὶ τὴν ξηρότητα ξηραίνειν ἀεί. τὸν γοῦν βοῤῥᾶν, ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἄνεμον τυγχάνοντα, ξηραίνειν ἅπαντα καὶ ψύχειν. καὶ τοῦτ’ εἶναι τὸ πρὸς Ὁμήρου λεγόμενον, Ὡς δ’ ὅτ’ ὀπωρινὸς βορέης νεοαρδέ’ ἀλωὴν Αἶψα ξηραίνει.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Now it would be time to speak also about the temperaments [mixtures] themselves. The prevailing opinion of the most distinguished physicians and philosophers is that there is a hot and moist temperament, another that is moist and cold, and a third after these that is dry and cold, another that is both dry and hot. But some of them say that there exists a certain temperament that is both moist and cold, and another that is both hot and dry; but neither one that is both moist and hot, nor one that is both cold and dry. For they claim it is not possible either for moisture to coincide with predominant heat, or for dryness to coincide with coldness. For moisture is consumed by prevailing heat, and thus the body becomes both hot and dry, while it remains undigested and unprocessed in those bodies where heat is weak, so that it is necessary, when heat predominates, for dryness to follow, and when coldness predominates, for moisture to accompany it.

These men, then, have convinced themselves in this way that there are two differences of temperaments in all. But those who think there are four contradict them in two ways: some immediately refuse to accept the first axiom, that it is necessary for moisture to be dried out by prevailing heat; while others grant this but dispute it differently. The first group says that the function of heat is to warm, just as that of cold is to cool, and again that of dryness is to dry, just as that of moisture is to moisten. And for this reason, those bodies which are hot and dry by nature, like fire, insofar as they are hot, warm things, and insofar as they are dry, dry them. But those which are moist and hot, like hot water, these are naturally always suited to moisten and warm, with each quality here too having its own inseparable function. Therefore they do not concede that if something is warming, this immediately also dries; but if moisture is added to heat, it warms and moistens at the same time, like baths of fresh water; but if, just as it is hot, so it is also dry, like fire, it not only warms but also immediately dries, taking this not from its heat but from the dryness accompanying it.

They remind us here of those who have spent too much time in the summer sun and then, as is natural, have become parched, having their whole body both dry and rough, and thirsting unbearably. For they say the cure for them is ready and easy, not only if they drink, but also if they bathe in hot, fresh waters, since moisture, whether with coldness or with heat, is able to perform its own function, for it moistens things that come near. By the same reasoning they say that dryness also always dries. The north wind, at any rate, being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools everything. And this is what is said by Homer: "As when the autumn north wind quickly dries the newly-watered field."
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
It is now time to speak about the temperaments [Gr. *kraseis*, lit. "mixtures"] themselves. The majority opinion, indeed, of the most eminent physicians and philosophers, is that there is one temperament that is moist and hot, another that is moist and cold, a third after these that is dry and cold, and one that is at once dry and hot.

But some of them say that a certain temperament that is at once moist and cold exists, and another that is at once hot and dry; not, however, one that is at once moist and hot, nor one that is at once cold and dry. For they claim it is not possible for moisture to coexist with a predominating heat, nor for dryness to coexist with coldness. For moisture, they argue, is consumed by a prevailing heat, and thus the body becomes at once hot and dry; while it [moisture] remains undigested and unprocessed in those bodies in which the natural heat is weak, so that it is necessary, when heat is dominant, for dryness to follow, and when coldness has the upper hand, for moisture to ensue. These thinkers, then, have persuaded themselves on these grounds that the varieties of the temperaments are two in all.

But those who believe there are four argue against them in two ways: some, by not conceding the very first axiom, namely that moisture is necessarily dried out by a prevailing heat; while others concede this point, but dispute it on other grounds. The first group, then, says that the function of the hot is to heat, just as that of the cold is to cool, and in turn that of the dry is to dry, just as that of the moist is to moisten. And for this reason, whatever bodies are by nature at once hot and dry, such as fire, in that they are hot, they heat, and in that they are dry, they dry. But whatever bodies are moist and hot, such as hot water, are by nature suited always to moisten and to heat, with each quality here too possessing its own inseparable function. Therefore, they do not concede that if something is heating, it must immediately also be drying. But rather, if moisture is added to the heat, it heats and moistens at the same time, like baths of fresh water; but if, just as it is hot, it should also be dry, like fire, it not only heats but also immediately dries, deriving this latter effect not from its heat, but from the dryness that accompanies it.

And at this point they bring to mind the case of those who have spent too long in the summer sun and then, as is to be expected, have become parched, having their whole body dry and withered, and being unbearably thirsty. For they say that a ready and very easy cure for them is not only to drink, but also to bathe in hot, fresh waters, on the grounds that moisture, whether it is combined with coldness or with heat, is able to perform its own function, which is to moisten whatever it approaches. And according to the same line of reasoning, they say that dryness, too, always dries. The north wind [Boreas], for instance, being a dry and cold wind, dries and cools everything. And this, they say, is what is meant by the line from Homer: "As when the autumn north wind swiftly dries a newly-watered threshing floor."

paragraphs.content: Κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ τὸν τοῦ μήκωνος ὀπὸν καὶ ἄλλα μυρία φάρμακα ξηραίνειν ἅμα καὶ ψύχειν. ὥστ’ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον, οὔτ’ εἴ τι ψυχρὸν, εὐθὺς τοῦτο καὶ ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχειν, οὔτ’, εἴ τι θερμὸν, εὐθὺς καὶ ξηρόν· οὔκουν οὐδὲ τὴν θερμὴν κρᾶσιν ἐξ ἀνάγκης εἶναι καὶ ξηρὰν, ἀλλὰ δύνασθαί ποτε τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ πλεονεκτεῖν ἐν τῇ κράσει τοῦ ζώου, τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τὴν γένεσιν, καὶ τὴν ἀλλοίωσιν, καὶ τὴν μεταβολὴν ἐκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γίνεσθαι. τίς γὰρ οὖν εἰπὼν, ὅτι τὸ λευκὸν ἠλλοιώθη τε καὶ μετέβαλεν, ἐγένετο γὰρ θερμὸν, οὐκ ἂν εἴη καταγέλαστος; ἐπιζητεῖ γὰρ ὁ λόγος, οὐ τὴν κατὰ ψυχρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀντίθεσιν, ἀλλὰ τὴν κατὰ τὸ χρῶμα μεταβολήν· μεταβάλλει γὰρ τὸ μὲν λευκὸν εἰς τὸ μέλαν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ μέλαν εἰς τὸ λευκὸν, καὶ τὸ θερμὸν αὖ εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ὥσπερ καὶ τὸ ψυχρὸν εἰς τὸ θερμόν. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν εἰς τὸ ξηρὸν, τὸ δ’ αὖ ξηρὸν εἰς τὸ ὑγρόν. εἰ γὰρ δὴ φάσκει τις ἠλλοιῶσθαι τὸ σῶμα τῷ τέως ὑγρὸν ὑπάρχον εἶναι νῦν λευκὸν, ἢ τῷ τέως ξηρὸν ὂν τὸ νῦν φαίνεσθαι μέλαν, οὐκ ἂν ὑγιαίνειν δόξειεν. εἰ δέ γε τὸ τέως ὑγρὸν τὸ νῦν ξηρὸν φαίη γενέσθαι, ἢ τὸ πρότερον ὑπάρχον μέλαν νῦν εἶναι λευκὸν, ἢ ἐκ θερμοῦ ψυχρὸν, ἢ ἐκ ψυχροῦ θερμὸν γεγονέναι, σωφρονεῖν ἂν δόξειεν ὁ τοιοῦτος, καὶ λέγειν τὰ εἰκότα. τὸ γὰρ μεταβάλλον, ᾗ μεταβάλλει, ταύτῃ μεταχωρεῖν δεῖ πρὸς τοὐναντίον. ἐγένετο γοῦν ἢ γίγνεται μουσικὸς ὅδε, φαμὲν, ἐξ οὐ μουσικοῦ δηλονότι, καὶ γραμματικὸς ἐξ οὐ γραμματικοῦ, καὶ ῥητορικὸς ἐξ οὐ ῥητορικοῦ· τὸ δ’ ἐκ μουσικοῦ γραμματικὸν, ἢ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸν, ἢ ἐξ ἄλλου τινὸς τῶν ἑτερογενῶν γίνεσθαί τι λέγειν ἄτοπον. ἐγχωρεῖ γὰρ τὸν τέως γραμματικὸν νῦν μουσικὸν γεγονέναι, προσκτησάμενον τῇ γραμματικῇ τὴν μουσικὴν, οὐκ ἀποβαλόντα τὴν γραμματικήν. καὶ μὴν εἰ προσεκτήσατό τι, μένοντος τοῦ προτέρου, παντί που δῆλον, ὡς οὐκ ἠλλοιώθη κατὰ τὸ μένον. ὥστ’ οὐκ ἐκ γραμματικοῦ μουσικὸς ἐγένετο· καὶ γὰρ καὶ νῦν ἔτι γραμματικός ἐστιν· ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀμούσου μουσικός· οὐ γὰρ ἔτ’ ἐγχωρεῖ μένειν αὐτὸν ἄμουσον, μουσικόν γε ἤδη γεγονότα. πασῶν γοῦν τῶν μεταβολῶν ὑπὸ τῶν ἐναντίων τε κᾀκ τῶν ἐναντίων εἰς τὰ ἐναντία γιγνομένων, δηλονότι καὶ τὸ ὑγρὸν, εἰ μεταβάλλει ποτὲ, καθ’ ὅσον ὑγρὸν, αὐτό τε ξηρανθήσεται καὶ τὸ ξηραῖνον αὐτὸ ξηρὸν λεχθήσεται. μὴ τοίνυν λεγόντων, φασὶν, ὡς θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ γενέσθαι. θερμὴν μὲν γὰρ ἅμα καὶ ψυχρὰν εἶναι τὴν αὐτὴν, ἢ ὑγρὰν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὰν οὐκ ἐγχωρεῖ· συνυπάρχειν γὰρ ἀλλήλαις οὐχ οἷόν τε καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὰς ἐναντίας ποιότητας· ἅμα δ’ ὑγρόν τι καὶ θερμὸν, καὶ ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν εἶναι δυνατὸν, ὡς ὅ τε λόγος ἀπέδειξε καὶ τὰ σμικρῷ πρόσθεν εἰρημένα παραδείγματα. τοιοῦτος μὲν οὖν ὁ τῶν προτέρων λόγος. ὁ δὲ τῶν δευτέρων οὐδὲν ἄτοπον εἶναί φησιν, ὑποκειμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ δραστικωτάτου τῶν τεττάρων, ὡς μὴ μόνον εἰς τὸ ψυχρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ εἰς τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐνεργεῖν, εἶναι κρᾶσιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ὅταν ἐς ταὐτὸ ἅμα συνέλθῃ πλῆθος ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου. ὁ δὲ λόγος ἐκείνων οὐχ, ὡς οὐκ ἄν ποτε γένοιτο καθ’ ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ σῶμα τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, τὸ δὲ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ, δείκνυσιν, ἀλλ’ ὡς οὐκ ἂν διαμείναι τοιοῦτο ἄχρι παντός· ἀεὶ γὰρ ἐξικμαζόμενον ὑπὸ τοῦ θερμοῦ τὸ ὑγρὸν ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἀποδείξει τὸ σῶμα· καὶ οὕτως οὐκ ἂν ἔτι θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν, ἀλλὰ θερμὸν εἴη καὶ ξηρόν· αὐτὸ δ’ οὖν πάλιν τοῦτο, τὸ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ χρόνῳ ξηρὸν ἔσται καὶ ψυχρόν. ἐπειδὰν γὰρ ἐκβοσκήσηται τὴν ἰκμάδα πᾶσαν αὐτοῦ τὸ θερμὸν, ἄρχεται τοὐντεῦθεν ἤδη, φασὶ, καὶ αὐτὸ μαραίνεσθαι, μηκέτ’ εὐποροῦν τροφῆς, ὅθεν ἐξήπτετο. θαυμαστὸν οὖν οὐδὲν εἶναι νομίζουσι, καὶ κατ’ ἀρχὰς μὲν εὐθὺς ἐν τῇ πρώτῃ γενέσει τοῦ ζώου συνδραμεῖν εἰς ταὐτὸ ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ πλέον, ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ. δυνατὸν δὲ κᾀν τῷ χρόνῳ προϊόντι γίνεσθαι τὴν τέως θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν κρᾶσιν αὖθις θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν, ὥσπερ γε καὶ αὖθις πάλιν τὴν ξηρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ἀποσβεννυμένου τοῦ θερμοῦ, ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἀποτελεσθῆναι. ὅτι μὲν οὖν ἐγχωρεῖ καὶ θερμὴν ἅμα καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί τινα, καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ξηρὰν ἑτέραν τῆσδε κρᾶσιν, ἐκ τούτων ἀποδεικνύουσιν. ὅτι δὲ πλείους τῶν τεττάρων διαφορὰς κράσεων ἀδύνατον ὑπάρχειν, ἐκ τῶνδε πειρῶνται διδάσκειν. ὑποκειμένων γὰρ, φασὶ, τεττάρων ποιοτήτων, εἰς ἀλλήλας τε τὸ δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ἐχουσῶν, θερμότητός τε καὶ ψυχρότητος, καὶ ξηρότητος καὶ ὑγρότητος, ἀντιθέσεις γίνεσθαι δύο, τὴν μὲν ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ θερμὸν ἀντίκειται τῷ ψυχρῷ, τὴν δ’ ἑτέραν, ἐν ᾗ τὸ ξηρὸν τῷ ὑγρῷ, καὶ διὰ τοῦτο τέτταρας ἀποτελεῖσθαι τὰς πάσας συζυγίας. ἓξ μὲν γὰρ γίνεσθαι τῶν τεττάρων ἀλλήλαις ἐπιπλεκομένων τὰς συζεύξεις, ἀλλὰ τὰς δύο τούτων ἀδυνάτους ὑπάρχειν. οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ ξηρὸν, οὔτε ψυχρὸν ἅμα καὶ θερμὸν δύναται γενέσθαι σῶμα. λείπεται γοῦν τέτταρας εἶναι συζυγίας κράσεων, ὑγρὰς μὲν δύο, ξηρὰς δὲ δύο, θερμότητι καὶ ψυχρότητι διῃρημένας. ἃ μὲν οὖν οἱ χαριέστατοι τῶν πρὸ ἡμῶν ἰατρῶν τε καὶ φιλοσόφων εἰρήκασι, ταῦτά ἐστιν. ἃ δ’ ἐγὼ παραλιπεῖν αὐτοὺς νομίζω, λέγειν ἤδη καιρός.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
**Translation of Paragraph 2.2:**

In the same manner, poppy juice and countless other drugs both dry and cool at the same time. Therefore, it is not necessary that if something is cold, it must immediately also be moist, nor if something is hot, must it immediately also be dry. Consequently, neither must a hot temperament necessarily also be dry, but it is possible that sometimes the hot may predominate over the cold in an animal's temperament, while the moist predominates over the dry. For indeed, generation, alteration, and change occur from opposites into opposites. For who, saying that white has been altered and changed because it became hot, would not be ridiculous? For the argument seeks not the opposition between cold and hot, but the change in color; for white changes into black, just as black changes into white, and hot in turn changes into cold, just as cold changes into hot. In the same way, the moist changes into the dry, and the dry in turn into the moist. For if someone claims that a body has been altered because what was previously moist is now white, or because what was previously dry now appears black, he would not seem to be in his right mind. But if he were to say that what was previously moist has now become dry, or what was formerly black is now white, or has become cold from hot, or hot from cold, such a person would seem sensible and to be saying reasonable things. For what changes must, in the respect in which it changes, move toward its opposite. We say, then, that this person has become or is becoming musical, obviously from being non-musical, and literate from being illiterate, and rhetorical from being non-rhetorical; but to say that someone becomes literate from being musical, or musical from being literate, or something from any other heterogeneous thing, is absurd. For it is possible for someone who was previously literate to have now become musical, having acquired music in addition to literacy, not having lost literacy. And surely, if he acquired something while the former remained, it is clear to everyone that he was not altered with respect to what remained. Therefore, he did not become musical from being literate; for he is still literate even now; but he became musical from being unmusical; for it is no longer possible for him to remain unmusical, having already become musical. Since all changes occur by opposites and from opposites into opposites, clearly the moist too, if it ever changes insofar as it is moist, will itself be dried and what dries it will be called dry. Therefore, they say, let them not claim that a temperament cannot be both hot and moist at the same time. For while the same thing cannot be both hot and cold at once, or both moist and dry at once—for opposite qualities cannot coexist in one and the same body—it is possible for something to be both moist and hot at once, and both cold and dry at once, as both reason has demonstrated and the examples given a little earlier.

Such, then, is the argument of the first group. The argument of the second group says there is nothing absurd, given that heat is the most active of the four [qualities], in its acting not only upon the cold but also upon the moist, for there to be a moist and hot temperament when an abundance of both moisture and heat come together at once right at the first generation of the animal. Their argument shows not that there could never be more moist than dry and more hot than cold in one and the same body, but that such a state could not remain forever; for the moist, being constantly evaporated by the hot, will in time make the body dry; and thus it would no longer be hot and moist, but would be hot and dry. And this very thing again, the hot and dry, with the advance of time will become dry and cold. For when the hot has consumed all its moisture, they say it then begins from that point to waste away itself, no longer having an abundance of nourishment from which it was kindled. They think it is therefore not at all surprising that even at the beginning, right at the first generation of the animal, either more moist than dry or more hot than cold should come together in the same place. And it is possible that in the course of time a temperament that was previously hot and moist should become hot and dry again, just as again the dry and hot temperament, when the heat is extinguished, may become cold and dry.

That it is possible for something to be both hot and moist at once, and for another temperament to be cold and dry, they demonstrate from these arguments. That it is impossible for there to be more than four different temperaments, they attempt to teach from the following: Given, they say, four qualities that have the capacity to act upon and be affected by one another—heat and cold, and dryness and moisture—two oppositions arise, one in which hot is opposed to cold, the other in which dry is opposed to moist, and therefore all the combinations come to four. For while six combinations arise from the four [qualities] being interwoven with one another, two of these are impossible. For a body cannot be both moist and dry at once, nor cold and hot at once. There remain, then, four combinations of temperaments: two moist ones and two dry ones, distinguished by heat and cold.

These, then, are the things that the most elegant of the physicians and philosophers before us have said. But it is now time to speak about what I think they have omitted.

paragraphs.content: Ἕν μὲν δὴ καὶ πρῶτον, ὅτι τὴν εὔκρατον φύσιν, ὥσπερ οὐκ ἀρετῇ τε ἅμα καὶ δυνάμει προὔχουσαν, ἐπελάθοντό τε καὶ τελέως παρέλιπον, ὥσπερ μηδ’ ὅλως οὖσαν, καίτοι μηδὲ φθέγξασθαί τι χωρὶς ἐκείνης ὑπὲρ τῶν ἄλλων δυνάμενοι. τὸ γοῦν ἐν τῇ θερμῇ κράσει πλεονεκτεῖν τὸ θερμὸν, ἢ ἐν τῇ ψυχρᾷ τὸ ψυχρὸν, οὐδ’ ἐπινοῆσαι δυνατὸν ἄνευ τοῦ πρότερον ἐπιθέσθαι τὴν εὔκρατον. οὐδὲ γὰρ οὐδὲ τὴν ὑγιεινὴν δίαιταν εἰς ἄλλο τι βλέποντες ἐξευρίσκουσιν, ἢ τὴν εὔκρατον ἐκείνην φύσιν· τὸ μὲν θερμότερον τοῦ δέοντος σῶμα κελεύοντες ἐμψύχειν, τὸ δ’ αὖ ψυχρότερον θερμαίνειν· ὡσαύτως τὸ μὲν ὑγρότερον ξηραίνειν, τὸ δὲ ξηρότερον ὑγραίνειν, ἀντεισάγοντες ἀεὶ δηλονότι τῷ πλεονάζοντι τὸ λεῖπον, ὡς εὔκρατόν τινα καὶ μέσην ἐργάσασθαι κατάστασιν. ἣν οὖν ἀεὶ μεταδιώκουσιν, καὶ πρὸς ἣν ἀποβλέποντες ἐπανορθοῦνται τὰς δυσκράτους, ἐγὼ μὲν ἠξίουν ἁπασῶν πρῶτον λέγεσθαι πρὸς αὐτῶν. οἳ δ’ ἄρα τοσοῦτον ἀποδέουσι τοῦ μεμνῆσθαι ταύτης, ὥσθ’ ὅλως παραλείπουσιν αὐτήν. ἀλλ’ οὐ παραλέλειπται, φασὶν ἐξ αὐτῶν ἔνιοι, ἐν γὰρ τῇ θερμῇ καὶ ὑγρᾷ περιέχεται. καὶ πῶς οὐχὶ πέντε λέγετε τὰς πάσας εἶναι κράσεις, ἀλλὰ τέτταρας, εἴπερ τῆς ἀρίστης μέμνησθε; δυοῖν γὰρ θάτερον, ἢ τῶν δυσκράτων ἀνάγκη παραλελεῖφθαι μίαν, ἢ τὴν εὔκρατον. ἐγὼ μὲν δὴ σαφῶς οἶδα τὴν εὔκρατον αὐτοὺς παραλιπόντας, ἐξ ὧν ἀξιοῦσιν. ἐπειδὰν γὰρ θερμὴν καὶ ξηρὰν, καὶ ψυχρὰν καὶ ὑγρὰν, ἤ τινα ἄλλην λέγωσι κρᾶσιν, οὐ τῶν ἄκρων ἀκούειν ἡμᾶς χρῆναι ποιοτήτων, ἀλλὰ κατὰ τὴν πλεονεκτοῦσαν ἀεὶ γίνεσθαι προσηγορίαν. εἰ δ’ οὐ βούλονται τὴν εὔκρατον παραλελεῖφθαι, τῶν ἄλλων τινὰ δειχθήσονται παραλιπόντες. ἔστω γὰρ εὔκρατον εἶναι τὴν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν, ὥσπερ αὐτοὶ βούλονται. παραλελοίπασιν ἄρα σαφῶς τὴν ἀντικειμένην τῇ ψυχρᾷ καὶ ξηρᾷ δυσκρασίᾳ, ἐν ᾗ τὸ ὑγρὸν πλεονεκτεῖ καὶ τὸ θερμόν. ἀλλ’ αὐτὴ, φασὶν, ἐστὶν ἥδε. καὶ πῶς ἐνδέχεται καὶ πλεονεκτεῖν ἅμα τὸ θερμὸν καὶ μὴ πλεονεκτεῖν, καὶ κρατεῖσθαι καὶ μὴ κρατεῖσθαι τὸ ψυχρόν; εἰ μὲν γὰρ εὔκρατός ἐστιν, οὐδὲν οὐδενὸς ἀμέτρως ἐπικρατεῖ, εἰ δὲ δύσκρατος, ἀνάγκη πλεονεκτεῖν τι τῶν ἐκ τῆς ἀντιθέσεως. ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ τοῦτο, φασὶν, ἴδιόν ἐστι τῆς εὐκράτου, τὸ κρατεῖν ἐν αὐτῇ τὸ μὲν θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ, τὸ δ’ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ· κρατήσαντος γὰρ τοῦ ψυχροῦ, μετρίως μὲν, οὐκ ἀγαθὴν εἶναι τὴν κρᾶσιν, ἔτι δὲ μᾶλλον, νόσον ἤδη γίνεσθαι, καθάπερ, εἰ καὶ σφοδρῶς κρατήσειε, θάνατον· οὕτω δὲ κᾀπὶ τοῦ ξηροῦ συμπίπτειν ἐν ἀρχῇ μὲν δυσκρασίαν, ἐπὶ πλέον δὲ νόσον, ἐπὶ πλεῖστον δὲ κρατήσαντος, θάνατον· ὥσπερ οὐχὶ κᾀπὶ τῆς ὑγρᾶς καὶ θερμῆς ταῦτα συμπίπτοντα. τίς γὰρ ἂν οὐχ ὁμολογήσειεν, ὡς, ἐπειδὰν μὲν ἐπ’ ὀλίγον ἢ τὸ θερμὸν τοῦ ψυχροῦ τύχοι πλεονεκτῆσαν, ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ, δυσκρασίαν οὕτως γιγνομένην· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἐπὶ πλέον, νόσον· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἐπὶ πλεῖστον, θάνατον. ὁ γὰρ αὐτὸς ἐπ’ ἀμφοῖν λόγος. ἢ μηδὲ τὰς ἀμέτρως ὑγρὰς καὶ θερμὰς καταστάσεις αἰτιώμεθα, μηδ’ ὅσα μεθ’ ὑγρότητος ἀμέτρου νοσήματα συνίσταται θερμὰ, μηδὲ ταῦτ’ ὁμολογῶμεν εἶναι νοσήματα. πρὸς δὴ τοὺς τοιούτους λόγους ἀπομαχόμενοί τινες τῶν ἀπ’ Ἀθηναίου τοῦ Ἀτταλέως ὁμόσε χωροῦσιν, οὔτε κατάστασιν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν μέμφεσθαι λέγοντες, οὔθ’ εὑρεθῆναί τι νόσημα φάσκοντες ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν, ἀλλὰ πάντως ἢ θερμὸν καὶ ξηρὸν ὑπάρχειν, ὡς τὸν πυρετὸν, ἢ ψυχρὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν, ὡς τὸν ὕδερον, ἢ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, ὡς τὴν μελαγχολίαν. ἐπιμέμνηνται δ’ ἐνταῦθα καὶ τῶν ὡρῶν τοῦ ἔτους, ὑγρὸν μὲν καὶ ψυχρὸν εἶναι τὸν χειμῶνα φάσκοντες, ξηρὸν δὲ καὶ θερμὸν τὸ θέρος, καὶ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν τὸ φθινόπωρον, εὔκρατον δ’ ἅμα καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν ὥραν καλοῦσι τὸ ἔαρ· οὕτω δὲ καὶ τῶν ἡλικιῶν τὴν παιδικὴν εὔκρατόν τε καὶ θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν εἶναί φασι. δηλοῦσθαι δὲ τὴν εὐκρασίαν αὐτῆς νομίζουσι κᾀκ τῶν ἐνεργειῶν τῆς φύσεως, ἐῤῥωμένων τηνικαῦτα μάλιστα. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ τὸν θάνατόν φασιν εἰς ξηρότητα καὶ ψύξιν ἄγειν τὰ τῶν ζώων σώματα. καλεῖσθαι γοῦν ἀλίβαντας τοὺς νεκροὺς, ὡς ἂν μηκέτι λιβάδα καὶ ὑγρότητα κεκτημένους οὐδεμίαν, ἐξατμισθέντας ἅμα διὰ τὴν ἀποχώρησιν τοῦ θερμοῦ, καὶ παγέντας ὑπὸ τῆς ψύξεως. ἀλλ’ εἴπερ ὁ θάνατος, φασὶ, τοιοῦτος, ἀναγκαῖον ἤδη τὴν ζωὴν, ὡς ἂν ἐναντίαν ὑπάρχουσαν αὐτῷ, θερμήν τε εἶναι καὶ ὑγράν· καὶ μὴν εἴπερ ἡ ζωὴ, φασὶ, θερμόν τι χρῆμα καὶ ὑγρόν ἐστιν, ἀνάγκη πᾶσα, καὶ τὴν ὁμοιοτάτην αὐτῇ κρᾶσιν ἀρίστην ὑπάρχειν, εἰ δὲ τοῦτο παντί που δῆλον, ὡς εὐκρατοτάτην, ὥστ’ εἰς ταὐτὸ συμβαίνειν ὑγρὰν καὶ θερμὴν φύσιν εὐκράτῳ, καὶ μηδὲν ἄλλο εἶναι τὴν εὐκρασίαν, ἢ τῆς ὑγρότητός τε καὶ θερμότητος ἐπικρατούσης. οἱ μὲν δὴ τῶν ἀμφὶ τὸν Ἀθήναιον λόγοι τοιοίδε. δοκεῖ δέ πως ἡ αὐτὴ δόξα καὶ Ἀριστοτέλους εἶναι τοῦ φιλοσόφου, καὶ Θεοφράστου γε μετ’ αὐτὸν, καὶ τῶν Στωϊκῶν, ὥστε καὶ τῷ πλήθει τῶν μαρτύρων ἡμᾶς δυσωποῦσιν. ἐγὼ δὲ περὶ μὲν Ἀριστοτέλους, ὅπως ἐγίνωσκεν ὑπὲρ θερμῆς καὶ ὑγρᾶς κράσεως, ἴσως ἂν, εἰ δεηθείη, ἐπὶ προήκοντι τῷ λόγῳ δείξαιμι· δοκοῦσι γάρ μοι παρακούειν αὐτοῦ.
paragraphs.openai_translation: First, then, to begin with: they forgot and completely left out the well-balanced nature [eukrasia: well-proportioned mixture/temperament], as though it did not at all exist, and as though it did not surpass in both excellence and power—although in fact they cannot even say anything about the other states apart from it. For it is impossible even to conceive that the hot has the advantage in a hot mixture, or the cold in a cold one, without first positing the well-balanced [state]. Nor, indeed, when they devise a healthy regimen, do they look to anything other than that well-balanced nature: they bid one to cool a body that is hotter than it should be, and to warm one that is too cold; likewise, to dry what is too moist, and to moisten what is too dry—always, clearly, introducing what is lacking as a counter to what is in excess, in order to produce a certain well-balanced, middle condition. This, then, is the state they are always pursuing, and by looking to it they correct the imbalanced [dyskrasiai: bad mixtures]; and I thought it should be the first of all to be mentioned by them. But they fall so far short of remembering it that they pass it over entirely. “But it has not been omitted,” some of them say; “it is contained in the hot-and-moist.” Then how is it that you say there are not five mixtures in all, but four, if indeed you have remembered the best one? For of the two alternatives, either one of the imbalanced states must have been omitted, or the well-balanced one. **Translation:**

One thing then, and first, is that they have forgotten and completely omitted the well-tempered nature, as if it did not excel in both virtue and power at once, as if it did not exist at all, even though they cannot say anything about the other [temperaments] without reference to it. For it is impossible even to conceive that the hot predominates in the hot temperament, or the cold in the cold temperament, without first positing the well-tempered one. Indeed, they devise a healthy regimen looking to nothing else than that well-tempered nature: commanding that a body hotter than it should be must be cooled, and one that is colder must be warmed; likewise, that the moister must be dried, and the drier moistened, always clearly introducing what is lacking to counter what is excessive, so as to produce a well-tempered and middle state. That which they are always pursuing, and looking to which they correct the ill-tempered states, I thought should be mentioned first of all by them. But they are so far from remembering this that they omit it entirely.

But it has not been omitted, some of them say, for it is contained in the hot and moist [temperament]. And how is it that you do not say there are five temperaments in all, but four, if you remember the best one? For one of two things is necessary: either one of the ill-tempered ones has been omitted, or the well-tempered one. I clearly know that they have omitted the well-tempered one, from what they maintain. For when they speak of hot and dry, or cold and moist, or any other temperament, they claim we should not understand the extreme qualities, but that the naming always occurs according to what predominates. But if they do not want the well-tempered one to have been omitted, they will be shown to have omitted one of the others.

For let the moist and hot be well-tempered, as they themselves wish. Then they have clearly omitted the one opposite to the cold and dry dyscrasia [ill-temperament], in which the moist and hot predominate. But this, they say, is that very one. And how is it possible for the hot both to predominate and not predominate at the same time, and for the cold both to be overcome and not be overcome? For if it is well-tempered, nothing excessively predominates over anything else; but if it is ill-tempered, something from the opposition must necessarily predominate.

But this very thing, they say, is characteristic of the well-tempered state, that in it the hot prevails over the cold, and the moist over the dry; for when the cold prevails, even moderately, the temperament is not good, and still more so, disease already occurs, just as if it should prevail strongly, death results; and so too with the dry, at first dyscrasia occurs, with more [predominance] disease, and with the greatest predominance, death. As if these same things did not also occur with the moist and hot [temperament]. For who would not agree that when either the hot happens to predominate over the cold by a small amount, or the moist over the dry, dyscrasia thus occurs; when by more, disease; when by the most, death? For the same reasoning applies to both.

Or should we not blame excessively moist and hot conditions, nor acknowledge as diseases those hot diseases that arise with excessive moisture? Against such arguments, some of the followers of Athenaeus of Attaleia fight back, saying they find no fault with a moist and hot condition, nor claiming that any disease is found to be moist and hot, but that all are either hot and dry, like fever, or cold and moist, like dropsy, or cold and dry, like melancholy.

They also mention here the seasons of the year, saying that winter is moist and cold, summer dry and hot, autumn cold and dry, and they call spring both well-tempered and hot and moist; and likewise of the ages [of life], they say childhood is well-tempered and hot and moist. They think its good temperament is shown also from the activities of nature, which are then especially vigorous. And indeed they say that death leads the bodies of living things to dryness and coldness. For the dead are called "alibantes" [without moisture], as no longer possessing any flow or moisture, having evaporated due to the departure of heat and having been frozen by the cooling.

But if death, they say, is such, then life, being its opposite, must necessarily be hot and moist; and indeed if life, they say, is something hot and moist, it is entirely necessary that the temperament most similar to it be the best, and if this is clear to everyone as being the most well-tempered, then the moist and hot nature coincides with the well-tempered one, and good temperament is nothing other than the predominance of moisture and heat.

Such then are the arguments of Athenaeus's followers. The same opinion seems somehow to belong also to Aristotle the philosopher, and to Theophrastus after him, and to the Stoics, so that they embarrass us with the multitude of witnesses. But I, regarding how Aristotle understood the hot and moist temperament, perhaps, if needed, will show this as the argument proceeds; for they seem to me to misunderstand him.
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
**Paragraph 3:**

First and foremost, then, is that they have both forgotten and completely omitted the well-tempered [eukratos] nature—as if it were not pre-eminent in both excellence and power, as if it did not exist at all—and yet they are unable to say a single thing about the other natures without it. For example, it is impossible even to conceive of the hot predominating in the hot temperament, or the cold in the cold one, without first positing the well-tempered one. For indeed, they devise the healthy regimen with an eye to nothing other than that well-tempered nature: they order that a body hotter than it should be is to be cooled, and one colder, in turn, is to be warmed; likewise, that one moister is to be dried, and one drier is to be moistened, clearly always introducing what is lacking to counteract what is in excess, so as to produce a certain well-tempered and intermediate state.

This state, then, which they always pursue, and looking to which they correct the ill-tempered ones, I, for my part, would have expected them to name first of all. But they, it turns out, are so far from remembering it that they omit it entirely. "But it has not been omitted," some of them say, "for it is contained in the hot and moist [temperament]." And how is it that you do not say there are five temperaments in all, but four, if you are indeed taking account of the best one? For one of two things is necessary: either one of the ill-tempered ones has been omitted, or the well-tempered one has. I, for my part, know clearly that they have omitted the well-tempered one, based on their own principles. For when they speak of a hot and dry, or a cold and moist, or any other temperament, they maintain that we are not to understand these as the extreme qualities, but that the designation is always given according to the one that predominates. But if they do not wish for the well-tempered one to have been omitted, they will be shown to have omitted one of the others. For let the moist and hot be the well-tempered one, as they themselves wish. Then they have clearly omitted the imbalance that is opposite to the cold and dry dyscrasia—that is, the one in which the moist and the hot predominate. "But this," they say, "is that very one." And how is it possible for the hot to predominate and at the same time not to predominate, and for the cold to be overcome and not be overcome? For if it is well-tempered, nothing prevails immoderately over anything else; but if it is ill-tempered, it is necessary for one of the opposites to predominate.

"But this very thing," they say, "is the distinctive property of the well-tempered state: that in it the hot prevails over the cold, and the moist over the dry. For if the cold prevails, even moderately, the temperament is not good; and if it prevails still more, it becomes a disease; just as, if it should prevail intensely, it results in death. And the same thing happens in the case of the dry: at first an imbalance, then with more, a disease, and when it prevails most of all, death." As if these things do not also happen in the case of the moist and hot temperament! For who would not agree that when the hot happens to predominate slightly over the cold, or the moist over the dry, an imbalance is thus produced; and when it does so to a greater degree, a disease; and when to the greatest degree, death? For the same principle applies to both sides. Or else, let us not blame immoderately moist and hot conditions, nor admit that those diseases which are established with immoderate moistness and heat are diseases at all.

Now, fighting back against such arguments, some from the school of Athenaeus of Attaleia go on the offensive, saying that they neither find fault with a moist and hot condition, nor do they maintain that any disease is found to be moist and hot, but that a disease is always either hot and dry, like fever; or cold and moist, like dropsy; or cold and dry, like melancholy. And at this point they also bring up the seasons of the year, stating that winter is moist and cold, summer is dry and hot, and autumn is cold and dry; but spring they call a season that is at once well-tempered, hot, and moist. And in the same way, they say that among the ages of life, childhood is well-tempered, hot, and moist. And they think its well-tempered state is also shown by the activities of nature, which are strongest at that time. And indeed, they also say that death leads the bodies of living creatures into a state of dryness and coldness. At any rate, the dead are called *alibantes* [lifeless/un-moistened], as if they no longer possess any *libas* [stream] or moisture, having been evaporated by the departure of their heat and solidified by the cold. "But if death," they say, "is of such a nature, it is then necessary for life, being its opposite, to be both hot and moist. Moreover, if life," they say, "is something hot and moist, it is absolutely necessary that the temperament most like it be the best; and if this is clearly the most well-tempered one, it follows that the hot and moist nature is identical to the well-tempered one, and that the well-tempered state is nothing other than the predominance of moistness and heat."

Such, then, are the arguments of the school of Athenaeus. And this same opinion also seems to be that of the philosopher Aristotle, and of Theophrastus after him, and of the Stoics, so that they overwhelm us with the number of their witnesses. But as for Aristotle and what he thought about the hot and moist temperament, I could perhaps show, if it were necessary and when my argument has advanced further, that they seem to me to have misheard him.

paragraphs.content: Τὸ δέ γε νῦν εἶναι, πειράσομαι πρῶτον ἐνδείξασθαι τοῖς λέγουσι ταῦτα, πῆ ποτε σοφίζονται σφᾶς αὐτοὺς, εἶτ’ ἐφεξῆς ἐπιδεῖξαι τὸν ἅπαντα λόγον, εἰς ἓν ἀθροίσας κεφάλαιον. ὅτι μὲν δὴ τὸ ἔαρ οἴονται θερμὸν εἶναι καὶ ὑγρὸν ἅμα καὶ εὔκρατον, ἐντεῦθεν σοφίζονται προφανῶς. οὔτε γὰρ ὑγρὸν ὡς χειμὼν, οὔτε θερμὸν ὡς τὸ θέρος, ὥστ’ οὐδέτερον ἀμέτρως. ἀμετρίας δ’ ἦν ἕκαστον τῶν τοιούτων ὀνομάτων, καὶ κατ’ αὐτοὺς ἐκείνους, δηλωτικόν. διχῶς δ’ ἐσφάλησαν, πρῶτον μὲν ἐκ τοῦ βούλεσθαι πάντως ἐν ταῖς ὥραις εὑρεῖν τὴν τετάρτην συζυγίαν τῶν κράσεων, ἔπειτα δ’ ἐκ τοῦ καὶ θερμότερον ἢ κατὰ τὸν χειμῶνα, καὶ ὑγρότερον ἢ κατὰ τὸ θέρος ὑπάρχειν αὐτό. ἀλλ’ οὔτ’ ἀναγκαῖον ἐν ταῖς ὥραις ὑποτίθεσθαι τὴν τετάρτην συζυγίαν τῶν κράσεων, εἰ μὴ καὶ φαίνοιτο, καὶ τὸ παραβάλλειν αὐτὸ ταῖς ἑκατέρωθεν ὥραις οὐδὲν μᾶλλον ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἢ ψυχρὸν ἀποδείξει καὶ ξηρόν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ἀμετρίας ἐστὶν ὀνόματα τὸ ὑγρὸν καὶ τὸ θερμὸν, οὐκ ἀληθεύεται κατ’ αὐτούς· σύμμετρον γὰρ ἐν ἅπασι τὸ ἔαρ. εἰ δ’, ὅτι θέρους μέν ἐστιν ὑγρότερον, χειμῶνος δὲ θερμότερον, ὑγρόν ἐστι καὶ θερμὸν, οὐδὲν ἦττον αὐτὸ ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν νομίζεσθαι προσήκει, διότι θέρους μέν ἐστι ψυχρότερον, χειμῶνος δὲ ξηρότερον. ἢ τίς ἀποκλήρωσις, ἓν μὲν τῶν ἐκ τῆς ἀντιθέσεως ἀπὸ τοῦ χειμῶνος, ἓν δὲ ἀπὸ τοῦ θέρους λαμβάνειν; ἐν ἑκατέραις γὰρ ἀμφοτέρων διαφέρον, οὐκ ἐξ ἡμίσεως ὀφείλει τὴν παραβολὴν, ἀλλ’ ὁλόκληρον ἴσχειν. καὶ μὴν εἴπερ οὕτως γίνοιτο, τἀναντία φήσομεν ὑπάρχειν αὐτῷ. θερμὸν μὲν γὰρ ἔσται καὶ ξηρὸν, εἰ τῷ χειμῶνι, ψυχρὸν δ’ αὖ καὶ ὑγρὸν, εἰ τῷ θέρει παραβάλλοιτο. κατ’ οὐδετέραν οὖν τῶν παραβολῶν ὁλοκλήρως γινομένην ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἔσται. εἰ δ’ ἔξεστιν ἐκείνοις ἐξ ἑκατέρας αὐτῶν ἥμισυ λαβοῦσιν ὑγρὸν ἀποφαίνειν αὐτὸ καὶ θερμὸν, ἐξέσται δήπου καὶ ἡμῖν ἐπὶ θάτερον ἥμισυ μετελθοῦσιν ξηρὸν καὶ ψυχρὸν ἀποφῇναι, ξηρὸν μὲν ὡς πρὸς, τὸν χειμῶνα, ψυχρὸν δὲ ὡς πρὸς τὸ θέρος. ἅπαντα οὖν οὕτως ἔσται τὸ ἔαρ, ὑγρὸν, ξηρὸν, θερμὸν, ψυχρόν. ἀλλ’ οὐδὲ κατ’ αὐτοὺς ἐκείνους οἶόν τέ ἐστιν ἐν ἑνὶ καὶ ταὐτῷ πράγματι τὰς τέτταρας ἐπικρατῆσαι ποιότητας· οὔκουν οὔτε θέρει παραβαλεῖν· οὔτε χειμῶνι τὸ ἔαρ, ἀλλ’ αὐτὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ σκοπεῖσθαι δίκαιον. οὐδὲ γὰρ οὐδὲ τὸν χειμῶνα διὰ τοῦτο λέγομεν ὑγρὸν εἶναι καὶ ψυχρὸν, ὅτι τῶν ἄλλων ὡρῶν ἐστιν ὑγρότατος καὶ ψυχρότατος. ἀλλὰ τοῦτο μὲν καὶ ἄλλως αὐτῷ συμβέβηκεν· ὅτι δὲ πλεονεκτεῖ κατ’ αὐτὸν ἡ μὲν ὑγρότης τῆς ξηρότητος, ἡ δὲ ψυχρότης τῆς θερμότητος, διὰ τοῦτο ψυχρὸς εἶναι καὶ ὑγρὸς λέγεται. κατὰ ταὐτὸ δὲ καὶ τὸ θέρος, ὅτι κᾀν τούτῳ τὸ μὲν ὑγρὸν ἀπολείπεται τοῠ ξηροῦ, τὸ δὲ ψυχρὸν τοῦ θερμοῦ, διὰ τοῦτο θερμὸν εἶναι λέγεται καὶ ξηρόν. καὶ γὰρ δίκαιον, ἐκ τῆς οἰκείας φύσεως ἑκάστην τῶν ὡρῶν ἐξεταζομένην, οὐ πρὸς ἄλλην τινὰ παραβαλλομένην, ἢ θερμὴν, ἢ ψυχρὰν, ἢ ξηρὰν, ἢ ὑγρὰν ὀνομάζεσθαι. καὶ δὴ καὶ σκοπουμένῳ σοι κατὰ τάδε φανεῖται τὸ ἔαρ ἀκριβῶς μέσων ἁπασῶν τῶν ὑπερβολῶν. οὔτε γὰρ ὡς ἐν χειμῶνι πλεονεκτεῖ τὸ ψυχρὸν ἐν αὐτῷ τοῦ θερμοῦ, οὔθ’ ὡς ἐν θέρει πλεονεκτεῖται. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ ξηρότητός τε καὶ ὑγρότητος ἰσομοιρία τίς ἐστιν ἐν αὐτῷ, μήθ’ ὡς ἐν θέρει κρατοῦντος τοῦ ξηροῦ, μήθ’ ὡς ἐν χειμῶνι τοῦ ὑγροῦ. διὰ τοῦτο ὀρθῶς εἴρηται πρὸς Ἱπποκράτους, ἦρ δὲ ὑγιεινότατον καὶ ἥκιστα θανατῶδες. ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ φθινόπωρον ἧττον μὲν ἢ τὸ θέρος θερμὸν, ἧττον δὲ ἢ ὁ χειμὼν ψυχρόν. ὥστε ταύτῃ μὲν οὔτε θερμὸν ἁπλῶς, οὔτε ψυχρὸν, ἀμφότερα γάρ ἐστι, καὶ οὐδέτερον ἄκρως. ἕτερον δέ τι πρόσεστιν αὐτῷ κακὸν, ὅπερ ἐπεσημήνατο καὶ Ἱπποκράτης ἐν ἀφορισμοῖς λέγων· ὁκόταν τῆς αὐτῆς ἡμέρης, ὁτὲ μὲν θάλπος, ὁτὲ δὲ ψύχος γίγνηται, φθινοπωρινὰ τὰ νοσήματα προσδέχεσθαι χρή. καὶ τοῦτό ἐστι τὸ μάλιστα νοσῶδες ἐργαζόμενον τὸ φθινόπωρον, ἡ ἀνωμαλία τῆς κράσεως. οὐκ ὀρθῶς οὖν εἴρηται ψυχρὸν καὶ ξηρὸν, οὐ γάρ ἐστι ψυχρὸν αὐτὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ θεωρούμενον, ὥσπερ ὁ χειμὼν, ἀλλὰ τῷ θέρει παραβαλλόμενον, ἐκείνου ψυχρότερον. οὐ μὴν οὐδ’ ὁμαλῶς εὔκρατον, ὡς τὸ ἔαρ, ἀλλ’ ὅτι μάλιστα τούτῳ διενήνοχεν ἐκείνης τῆς ὥρας, ὅτι τὴν εὐκρασίαν τε καὶ τὴν ὁμαλότητα διὰ παντὸς ἴσην οὐ κέκτηται. πολὺ γὰρ θερμότερόν ἐστι κατὰ τὴν μεσημβρίαν, ἢ κατὰ τὴν ἕω τε καὶ τὴν ἑσπέραν. ὑγρότητι δὲ καὶ ξηρότητι μέσον μὲν οὐκ ἔστιν ἀκριβῶς, ὡς τὸ ἔαρ, ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ τὸ ξηρότερον ῥέπει. λείπεται δὲ κᾀν τούτῳ τοῦ θέρους, οὐ μὴν τοσοῦτόν γε, ὅσον θερμότητι. δῆλον οὖν, ὡς οὐδὲ τὸ φθινόπωρον ἁπλῶς οὕτως ῥητέον, ὡς ἐκεῖνοι λέγουσι, ψυχρόν τε εἶναι καὶ ξηρόν. ἄκρως μὲν γὰρ οὐδέτερόν ἐστιν, ἐπικρατεῖ δ’ ἐν αὐτῷ τὸ ξηρὸν τοῦ ὑγροῦ. καὶ δικαίως ἂν λεχθείη ταύτῃ μὲν ξηρὸν, ἐν δὲ τῇ κατὰ θερμότητα καὶ ψυχρότητα διαφορᾷ μικτὸν ἐξ ἀμφοῖν καὶ ἀνώμαλον. ὥστ’ εἴπερ τὰς τέσσαρας συζυγίας τῶν κράσεων εἰς τὰς τέσσαρας ὥρας διανεῖμαι σπεύδουσιν, ἴστωσαν οὐ μόνον ἦρι κακῶς προσάψαντες ὑγρότητα καὶ θερμότητα κράσεως, ἀλλὰ καὶ φθινοπώρῳ ψυχρότητα καὶ ξηρότητα. καίτοι γε, εἰ καὶ τοῦτο συνεχωρεῖτο ξηρὸν εἶναι καὶ ψυχρὸν, οὐκ ἦν ἀναγκαῖον εὐθέως, ὑγρὸν εἶναι καὶ θερμὸν τὸ ἔαρ. οὐ γὰρ, εἰ τέτταρες αἱ πᾶσαι συζυγίαι τῶν ἀμέτρων κράσεων εἰσὶν, ἤδη πάσας ἀναγκαῖον εἰς τὰς τέσσαρας ὥρας νενεμῆσθαι. ἀλλ’ εἴπερ ἄρα τάξις τίς ἐστιν ἐν τῷ κόσμῳ, καὶ κατὰ τὸ βέλτιον, οὐ κατὰ τὸ χεῖρον ἅπαντα κεκόσμηται, πιθανώτερον ἦν, εὐκράτους μὲν τὰς πλείους ὥρας γεγενῆσθαι, μίαν δὲ ἐξ αὐτῶν, εἴπερ ἄρα, τὴν δύσκρατον. οἱ δέ γε τοὐναντίον ἀποδεῖξαι σπεύδουσιν, ὡς οὐδεμία τῶν ὡρῶν ἐστιν εὔκρατος, ἀλλ’ ἐξ ἀνάγκης ἐν αὐταῖς ἐπικρατεῖ νῦν μὲν τὸ θερμὸν, αὖθις δὲ τὸ ψυχρὸν, καὶ νῦν μὲν, εἰ τύχῃ, τὸ ξηρὸν, αὖθις δὲ τὸ ὑγρόν. ἐγὼ δὲ τοσοῦτον ἀποδέω τοῦ ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀποφαίνειν τὸ ἔαρ, ἢ, ὅ τί περ ἂν εὔκρατον ᾖ, θερμὸν καὶ ὑγρὸν εἶναι συγχωρεῖν, ὥστε πᾶν τοὐναντίον ἀποφαίνομαι, χειρίστην εἶναι κατάστασιν κράσεως τοῦ περιέχοντος ἀέρος τὴν θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν, ἣν ἐν μὲν ταῖς ὥραις οὐκ ἂν εὕροις ὅλως, ἐν δὲ ταῖς νοσώδεσί τε καὶ λοιμώδεσι καταστάσεσιν ἐνίοτε συμπίπτει, καθάπερ που καὶ ὁ Ἱπποκράτης ἐμνημόνευσε, λέγων· ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου. τοῦτο γάρ ἐστιν ἴδιον ὑγρᾶς καὶ θερμῆς καταστάσεως, ὕειν συνεχῶς ἐν καύμασιν. εἰ δ’ ἤτοι μόνον εἴη καῦμα, καθάπερ ἐπὶ τοῦ κατὰ φύσιν ἔχοντος θέρους, ἢ ὕει μὲν, ἀλλ’ ἐν κρύει, καθάπερ ἐν χειμῶνι, θερμὴν καὶ ὑγρὰν οὐχ οἶόν τε τὴν τοιαύτην εἶναι κατάστασιν. ἆρ’ οὖν ἄνοσον ἐκεῖνο τὸ θέρος, ἐν ᾧ, φησὶν, ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου; καὶ μὴν ἄνθρακας ἐν αὐτῷ γενέσθαι διηγεῖται, σαπέντων δηλονότι τῶν ἐν τῷ σώματι περιττωμάτων, καί τινας ἰχῶρας θερμοὺς καὶ ὑγροὺς ἀμέτρως γεννησάντων. εἴσῃ δὲ ἐξ αὐτῆς τῆς ῥήσεως, εἰ πᾶσαν αὐτήν σοι παραγράψαιμι, τόνδε τὸν τρόπον ἔχουσαν. ἄνθρακες ἐν Κρανῶνι θερινοί. ὗεν ἐν καύμασιν ὕδατι λάβρῳ δι’ ὅλου. ἐγίνοντο δὲ μᾶλλον Νότῳ· καὶ ὑπεγίνοντο μὲν ὑπὸ τὸ δέρμα ἰχῶρες· ἐγκαταλαμβανόμενοι δὲ ἐθερμαίνοντο, καὶ κνησμὸν ἐνεποίεον· εἶτα φλύκταιναι ὥσπερ πυρίκαυστοι ἐπανίσταντο, καὶ ὑπὸ τὸ δέρμα καίεσθαι ἐδόκεον. ἀλλ’ ἐνταῦθα μὲν, ὡς ἂν μιᾶς ὥρας μετακοσμηθείσης, ἧττον τὸ κακόν· εἰ δὲ δύο ἢ τρεῖς ὑπαλλαχθεῖεν, ἢ καὶ σύμπαν τὸ ἔτος ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν γένοιτο, μέγιστον ἀνάγκη συμπεσεῖν οὕτω λοιμὸν, οἶον ἐν τῷ τρίτῳ τῶν ἐπιδημιῶν διηγεῖται. παραγράψω δὲ πρῶτον μὲν ἅ περὶ τῆς τῶν ὡρῶν ἀκοσμίας εἶπεν, ἐφεξῆς δὲ καὶ τὰ περὶ τῆς ἐπιγινομένης φθορᾶς τῶν ἀνθρώπων. ἐν ἅπασι δ’ αὐτοῖς προσέχειν σε τὸν νοῦν ἀκριβῶς ἀξιῶ καὶ σκοπεῖσθαι, πρῶτον μὲν, ὁποῖόν τι πρᾶγμα θερμὴ καὶ ὑγρὰ κρᾶσίς ἐστιν, ὡς οὐδὲν ἦρι παρόμοιον, εὐκράτῳ χρήματι· δεύτερον δὲ, ὡς ἀναγκαῖον ἐν αὐτῇ σήπεσθαι πάντα. ἄρχεται μὲν οὖν ὁ Ἱπποκράτης τῆς διηγήσεως ὧδε. ἔτος νότιον, ἔπομβρον, ἄπνοια διὰ τέλεος. εἶτα τούτοις ἐπιφέρει τὰ κατὰ μέρος ἁπάσης τῆς καταστάσεως, ὄμβρους πολλοὺς ἐν θερμῇ καὶ νοτίᾳ καταστάσει γενέσθαι γράφων, εἶτ’ αὖθις τὸν σύμπαντα λόγον εἰς ἕν ἐπὶ τέλει κεφάλαιον ἀγαγὼν οὕτως. γενομένου δὲ τοῦ ἔτεος ὅλου, φησὶ, νοτίου, καὶ ὑγροῦ, καὶ μαλακοῦ, τάδε καὶ τάδε συνέπεσεν, ἃ ξύμπαντα μὲν ἀναγράφειν ἐν τῷδε τῷ λόγῳ μακρόν· ἔνεστι δὲ τῷ βουλομένῳ, λαβόντι τὸ τρίτον τῶν ἐπιδημιῶν, ἀναγινώσκειν τὰ κατὰ μέρος, εἰς ἕν ἅπαντα κεφάλαιον ἀναγόμενα, σηπεδόνα μεγίστην, ἧς καὶ αὐτῆς ὀνομαστὶ πολλάκις ὁ Ἱπποκράτης ἐπιμέμνηται, ποτὲ μὲν ὡδί πως λέγων· ἦν δὲ καὶ τὸ ῥεῦμα τὸ συνιστάμενον οὐ πύῳ ἴκελον, ἀλλὰ σηπεδών τις ἄλλη, καὶ ῥεῦμα πολὺ καὶ ποικίλον· ὁτὲ δὲ πάλιν ὡδί· καὶ ἐν αἰδοίοισιν ἄνθρακες οἱ κατὰ θέρος, καὶ ἄλλα, ἃ σῆψις καλέεται, καὶ ὡς ἐκ τῆς σήψεως ταύτης πολλοῖσι μὲν βραχίων καὶ πῆχυς ὅλως ἀπεῤῥύη, πολλοῖσι δὲ μηρὸς ἢ τὰ περὶ τὴν κνήμην ἀπεψιλοῦτο, καὶ ποῦς ὅλος. ἀλλὰ καὶ ὀστῶν, καὶ σαρκῶν, καὶ νεύρων, καὶ ἄρθρων ἐκπτώσεις ἐγίγνοντο μεγάλαι. καὶ ὅλως οὐδέν ἐστιν εὑρεῖν ὧν ἔγραψε παθημάτων, ὃ μὴ σηπεδόνος ἔγγονον ὑπάρχει, δεόντως. οὔτε γὰρ ὑπὸ τοῦ ξηροῦ τι σήπεσθαι πέφυκεν, οὔθ’ ὑπὸ τοῦ ψυχροῦ. μάθοις δ’ ἂν, εἰ θεάσαιο τά τε κρέα καὶ τὰ ἄλλα σύμπαντα τὰ πρὸς τῶν ἀνθρώπων ταριχευόμενα, τὰ μὲν ἁλσὶ, τὰ δ’ ἅλμῃ, τὰ δ’ ὄξει, τὰ δ’ ἄλλῳ τινὶ τῶν ξηραινόντων σκευαζόμενα καλῶς. μάθοις δὲ καὶ ὡς ἐν τῷ βοῤῥᾷ, ξηρῷ καὶ ψυχρῷ τὴν φύσιν ὑπάρχοντι, ἄσηπτα μέχρι πλεῖστον διαμένει πάντα· σήπεται δ’ ἑτοίμως ταῖς νοτίαις καταστάσεσιν. ἔστι γὰρ οὖν καὶ οὗτος ὁ ἄνεμος ὑγρὸς καὶ θερμός. ὥστε πᾶν τοὐναντίον ἡμεῖς ἀποφαινόμεθα τοῖς ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ὑπολαμβάνουσιν εἶναι τὸ ἔαρ. οὔτε γὰρ τοιοῦτό ἐστιν, οὔθ’ ὑγιεινὸν ἂν ἦν, εἴπερ ἦν τοιοῦτο. οἱ δὲ καὶ τοιοῦτο εἶναί φασιν αὐτὸ, καὶ διὰ τοῦθ’ ὑγιεινὸν ὑπάρχειν, ἐν ἀμφοτέροις ἁμαρτάνοντες, ὅσα τε ταῖς αἰσθήσεσιν ἔνεστι διαγνῶναι, καὶ ὅσα τῷ λόγῳ διασκέψασθαι. ταῖς μὲν γὰρ αἰσθήσεσιν ἔνεστιν ἐναργῶς μαθεῖν εὔκρατον ἀκριβῶς αὐτὸ, τῷ λόγῳ δ’ ἐξευρεῖν, ὡς διὰ τοῦτ’ ἔστιν ὑγιεινὸν, διότι μηδὲν ἐν αὐτῷ τῶν τεττάρων ἐπικρατεῖ. εἰ δέ γ’ ἤτοι τὸ θερμὸν ἐπεκράτει πολλῷ τοῦ ψυχροῦ, ἢ τὸ ὑγρὸν τοῦ ξηροῦ, σηπεδόνων τε ἂν ἦν εὔφορον οὕτω καὶ πασῶν τῶν ὡρῶν νοσωδέστατον. ἀλλ’ ἡ τῆς τῶν τεττάρων κράσεων ἰσομοιρία τῆς τε εὐκρασίας αὐτοῦ καὶ τῆς ὑγιείας αἰτία. πόθεν οὖν ἐπῆλθέ τισιν ἰατροῖς τε καὶ φιλοσόφοις ὑγρὸν καὶ θερμὸν ἀποφῄνασθαι τὸ ἔαρ; ἐκ τοῦ βουληθῆναι δηλονότι τὰς τέτταρας συζυγίας τῶν κράσεων εἰς τὰς τέτταρας ὥρας διανεῖμαι. τοῦτο δ’ αὐτὸ πάλιν ἐκ τοῦ παραλιπεῖν τὴν πρώτην ἁπασῶν, τὴν εὔκρατον, ἐγένετο. καὶ γὰρ οὖν καὶ διαιτημάτων, καὶ φαρμάκων, ἁπάντων τε τῶν ὄντων, εἰς τὰς τέτταρας ταύτας συζυγίας ἀνάγουσι τὰς διαφοράς.
paragraphs.openai_translation: As to the matter now before us, I will first try to show to those who say such things how they contrive their reasoning, and then, in sequence, set forth the whole argument, gathering it into a single head. That they think spring is at once warm and moist and well-tempered [eukratos: in good balance] is quite plainly the way they reason. For it is neither moist like winter nor warm like summer, and thus in neither respect excessive. Now each of those names indicates excess, even by their own account. They have erred in two ways, first by wishing absolutely to find among the seasons the fourth pairing [syzygia] of the mixtures [kraseis: combinations of qualities], and then by assuming that it is both warmer than winter and moister than summer. But it is neither necessary to posit the fourth pairing of mixtures among the seasons unless it also appears, nor will comparing it with the seasons on either side show it to be any more moist and warm than cold and dry. For if “the moist” and “the warm” are names of excess, then their claim is not true; for spring is proportionate in all respects. But if, because it is moister than summer and warmer than winter, it is moist and warm, then no less should it be considered cold and dry, since it is colder than summer and drier than winter. Or what sort of allotment is it, to take one of the contrasting pairings from winter and one from summer? For since in each of those it differs in both respects, the comparison ought not to be made by halves, but to stand complete. And indeed, if the comparison were made in this way, we would say that the contraries belong to it: it will be warm and dry if compared with winter, but cold and moist if compared with summer. Therefore, by neither comparison, taken as a whole, will it be moist and warm. And if they are permitted, by taking a half from each side, to pronounce it moist and warm, surely it will be permitted to us, by turning to the other half, to pronounce it dry and cold—dry in relation to winter, cold in relation to summer. Thus in this way spring will be all things: moist, dry, warm, cold. But even by their own account it is not possible for the four qualities to be predominant in one and the same subject; therefore one should compare spring neither with summer nor with winter, but examine it in itself. For we do not say winter is moist and cold for this reason—that it is the moistest and coldest of the seasons—but this has happened to it otherwise; and because in it moisture exceeds dryness and coldness warmth, on that account it is called cold and moist. And in the same way summer, because in it the moist is surpassed by the dry and the cold by the warm, is called warm and dry. It is just, then, that each of the seasons, examined in accordance with its own nature and not by comparison with some other, be named as warm, or cold, or dry, or moist. And in fact, if you examine the matter in this way, it will appear to you that spring lies precisely in the middle of all excesses. For neither, as in winter, does cold in it prevail over warmth, nor, as in summer, is it outmatched. And likewise there is in it a certain equal share of dryness and moisture, neither as in summer where the dry dominates, nor as in winter where the moist does. On this account it was rightly said by Hippocrates: “Spring is the most healthful and least deadly.” But autumn is less warm than summer and less cold than winter. So in this respect it is neither simply warm nor simply cold; it is both, and neither to an extreme. Yet there is some other fault in it, which Hippocrates also marked in the Aphorisms, saying: “Whenever in the same day at one time there is heat and at another time cold, one must expect autumnal diseases.” And this is what makes autumn especially disease-producing—the irregularity of its mixture [krasis]. It is therefore not correctly said to be cold and dry; for it is not cold when considered in itself, like winter, but only when compared with summer it is colder. Nor is it evenly well-tempered like spring; rather, it differs from that season most of all in that it does not possess a steady equality of good mixture [eukrasia] and evenness throughout. For it is much warmer at midday than in the morning or evening. As to moisture and dryness, it is not precisely in the middle, as spring is, but leans toward the drier side; and in this too it falls short of summer, though not so much as in warmth. It is clear, then, that neither should autumn be spoken of simply, as they say, as being both cold and dry. For it is neither of these to an extreme, though in it the dry predominates over the moist. And it would be rightly said in this respect to be dry, but, in the difference regarding warmth and cold, mixed of both and irregular. Therefore, if they are eager to distribute the four pairings of mixtures among the four seasons, let them know that they have wrongly assigned moisture and warmth to spring as a mixture, and likewise coldness and dryness to autumn. And yet even if this were conceded—that autumn is dry and cold—it would not at once be necessary that spring be moist and warm. For even if there are four in all the pairings of immoderate mixtures, it is not necessary that all be apportioned among the four seasons. Rather, if there is some order in the cosmos, and all things are arranged for the better and not for the worse, it would be more plausible that most of the seasons are well-tempered, and that only one of them, if at all, is ill-tempered [dyskritos/dyskratēs: of bad mixture]. But they are eager to prove the contrary—that no season is well-tempered, but of necessity now the warm prevails in them, then the cold, and now, perchance, the dry, and then the moist. I, for my part, am so far from declaring spring to be moist and warm, or from conceding that whatever is well-tempered is warm and moist, that I declare quite the opposite: the worst condition of mixture of the surrounding air is the warm and moist, which you would not find at all among the seasons, but which sometimes occurs in sickly and pestilential states, as Hippocrates somewhere also recorded, saying: “There was rain in heat, with scalding water, continuously.” For this is characteristic of a warm and moist condition—that it rains continuously in heats. But if there were only heat, as in a summer that is according to nature, or it rains indeed, but in cold, as in winter, it would be impossible for the condition to be such as to be warm and moist. Was that summer, then, free from disease, in which, he says, “there was rain in heat, with scalding water, continuously”? And he also relates that carbuncles [anthrakes] occurred in it, plainly because the superfluities in the body putrefied, producing certain ichors excessively warm and moist. **Translation of Paragraph 4:**

But as things now stand, I will first try to demonstrate to those who say these things how they are deceiving themselves, and then subsequently display the entire argument, gathering it into one main point. Now, the fact that they think spring is hot and moist at the same time and well-tempered - from this they are clearly engaging in sophistry. For it is neither moist like winter, nor hot like summer, so neither quality is excessive. But each of these terms was indicative of excess, even according to those very people. They have erred in two ways: first, from wanting at all costs to find the fourth combination of temperaments in the seasons, and second, from the fact that it [spring] is both warmer than in winter and moister than in summer. But it is not necessary to suppose the fourth combination of temperaments exists in the seasons unless it actually appears so, and comparing it to the seasons on either side will no more prove it moist and hot than cold and dry.

For if "moist" and "hot" are names of excesses, they are not true according to them; for spring is moderate in all things. But if it is moist and hot because it is moister than summer and warmer than winter, it should no less be considered cold and dry, because it is colder than summer and drier than winter. Or what kind of arbitrary selection is it to take one element from the opposition from winter and one from summer? For differing in both respects from each season, it ought not to have the comparison made halfway, but should have it complete. And indeed, if it were done this way, we would say opposite qualities belong to it. For it will be hot and dry if compared to winter, but cold and moist if compared to summer. According to neither comparison made completely will it be moist and hot.

But if it is permitted to them, taking half from each comparison, to declare it moist and hot, it will surely be permitted to us, turning to the other half, to declare it dry and cold - dry in relation to winter, cold in relation to summer. Thus spring will be everything: moist, dry, hot, cold. But even according to those very people, it is not possible for the four qualities to predominate in one and the same thing. Therefore, it is not right to compare spring either to summer or to winter, but to examine it in itself. For we do not say winter is moist and cold because it is the moistest and coldest of the other seasons. Rather, this happens to it incidentally; but because in it moisture predominates over dryness and coldness over heat, for this reason it is said to be cold and moist.

In the same way summer too, because in it the moist falls short of the dry and the cold of the hot, for this reason is said to be hot and dry. For it is right that each of the seasons, being examined from its own nature and not compared to any other, should be called either hot or cold or dry or moist. And indeed, examining it in this way, spring will appear to you precisely in the middle of all excesses. For neither does the cold predominate over the hot in it as in winter, nor is it predominated over as in summer. In the same way there is a kind of equal share of dryness and moisture in it, with neither the dry prevailing as in summer nor the moist as in winter. For this reason it was correctly said by Hippocrates: "Spring is most healthy and least deadly."

But autumn too is less hot than summer and less cold than winter. So in this respect it is neither simply hot nor cold, for it is both and neither extremely. But another evil is present in it, which Hippocrates also indicated in the Aphorisms, saying: "When on the same day there is sometimes warmth and sometimes cold, one must expect autumnal diseases." And this is what especially makes autumn disease-producing: the irregularity of temperament. Therefore it is not correctly said to be cold and dry, for it is not cold when considered in itself, like winter, but compared to summer, it is colder than that. Nor is it uniformly well-tempered like spring, but differs most from that season in that it does not possess temperance and uniformity equally throughout. For it is much hotter at midday than at dawn and evening. And in moisture and dryness it is not precisely in the middle like spring, but inclines toward the drier. It falls short of summer in this too, though not as much as in heat.

It is clear, then, that autumn should not simply be called, as they say, cold and dry. For it is neither quality extremely, but the dry predominates over the moist in it. And it might justly be called dry in this respect, but in the difference regarding heat and cold, mixed from both and irregular. So if they are eager to distribute the four combinations of temperaments among the four seasons, let them know that they have not only wrongly attributed moisture and heat of temperament to spring, but also coldness and dryness to autumn.

And yet, even if this were granted to be dry and cold, it was not immediately necessary for spring to be moist and hot. For if there are four combinations of immoderate temperaments in all, it is not yet necessary for all to be distributed among the four seasons. But if indeed there is some order in the cosmos, and all things are arranged according to the better rather than the worse, it would be more plausible that most seasons were made well-tempered, and one of them, if any, ill-tempered. But they are eager to prove the opposite, that none of the seasons is well-tempered, but necessarily in them now the hot predominates, then the cold, and now, perhaps, the dry, then the moist.

But I am so far from declaring spring moist and hot, or granting that whatever is well-tempered is hot and moist, that I declare quite the opposite: that the hot and moist condition of the surrounding air's temperament is the worst, which you would not find at all in the seasons, but sometimes occurs in diseased and pestilential conditions, as Hippocrates somewhere mentioned, saying: "It rained in the heat with violent water throughout." For this is characteristic of a moist and hot condition, to rain continuously in heat. But if there were only heat, as in a natural summer, or if it rains but in cold, as in winter, such a condition cannot be hot and moist.

Was that summer then disease-free, in which he says "it rained in the heat with violent water throughout"? And yet he relates that carbuncles occurred in it, clearly from the putrefaction of the excretions in the body, generating certain excessively hot and moist ichors [serum-like fluids]. You will know from the passage itself, if I transcribe it all for you, which goes like this: "Summer carbuncles in Cranon. It rained in the heat with violent water throughout. They occurred more with the south wind; and ichors formed under the skin; when trapped they became hot and caused itching; then blisters like burns rose up, and it seemed to burn under the skin."

But here, with only one season altered, the evil was less. But if two or three were changed, or the whole year became moist and hot, the greatest plague would necessarily occur, such as he describes in the third book of Epidemics. I will first transcribe what he said about the disorder of the seasons, and then what about the subsequent destruction of people. In all these matters I ask you to pay careful attention and consider: first, what kind of thing a hot and moist temperament is, how it is nothing like spring, a well-tempered thing; second, how everything must putrefy in it.

Hippocrates begins his narrative thus: "A southerly year, rainy, windlessness throughout." Then to these he adds the particulars of the whole condition, writing that many rains occurred in a warm and southerly condition, then again bringing the whole account to one heading at the end thus: "The whole year being," he says, "southerly and moist and mild, these and those things happened," all of which would be lengthy to record in this discourse.
