Does this fall under the senses mentioned, or is it said in some other way not yet described? For asphalt, resin, and suet, as well as oil and pitch, are potentially hot because they easily become actually hot; for they are very quickly set aflame and most clearly heat our bodies when applied to them. But chalcanthite, misy, mustard, natron, sweet flag, may-apple, costus, and pellitory appear hot when applied to us, some more and some less, yet they are not by nature apt to be set aflame. Are those, then, who consider only this point—whether they are not easily set aflame—deluding themselves? For they should have examined not this, but whether they cannot be made to glow like charcoal, since charcoal is no less fire than flame is. But flame comes from air being ignited, or some airy body, whereas charcoal comes from earth, or some earthy body. And indeed, up to this point the account seems to be entirely consistent with itself, for it appears that all those drugs which are easily ignited when they touch fire also heat us, unless something, because it is of coarse particles, is not easily admitted into the body. For this will be defined more fully in the works *On the Powers of Drugs*. However, all things that are observed to heat our body are readily ignited.

"How is it, then," they say, "that they do not seem hot to the touch?" I do not know why they say this. For if we were saying that each of the aforementioned things is actually and already hot, it would surely be astonishing that they do not seem hot to the touch. But as it is, we call such things 'potentially' hot because of their ability to become hot easily. It is therefore no wonder that they do not yet heat those who touch them. For just as a fire does not grow before the wood, overcome by it, is transformed, and this certainly happens in some amount of time, in the same way drugs are not transformed by the heat in animals unless they are first acted upon by that heat itself. For a person warmed by a fire or in the sun is heated in one way, and a person heated by each of the aforementioned drugs in another. For the former are actually hot, but none of the drugs are. Therefore, they cannot heat us until they become actually so, and they receive this actuality from us ourselves, just as dry reeds do from the fire. Thus, all pieces of wood are cold according to their own nature, but those that are drier and smaller change into fire easily, while those that are moister and larger require more time. It is no wonder, then, if drugs also require first to be broken down into small, fine particles, and second, to be in contact with our bodies for some time, however short, in order to become hot. But if you expect them to become hot immediately, without having first broken them down or heated them, you seem to me to have forgotten what 'potentially hot' signifies. For you are testing them as if they were actually hot.

And indeed, it is not surprising that a thing must first be heated in order to heat in return. For this happens also according to the analogy of the wood. At any rate, wood both preserves and increases a dying flame by first being heated by that very flame. It is therefore not at all unreasonable that the heat in animals uses such drugs as a kind of nourishment, just as fire uses wood. For this is indeed how it appears to happen. But if you were to sprinkle any of them, having worked it into a fine powder, onto a chilled body, it is not heated at all. And for this reason we rub chilled parts for a very long time with such drugs, at once kindling heat by the friction and rendering porous what was previously condensed by the cold, so that the drug may penetrate inside and, by interacting with the innate heat of the animal, be altered and heated. For if even the smallest part of it acquires heat in actuality, it thus transmits it to the whole in continuity, just as if you were to light the tip of a torch from a tiny spark; for the fire easily spreads over the whole torch, no longer needing the spark.

Each of the things that are potentially hot, therefore, does not yet have in its nature a predominance of the hot over the cold, but it is already close to having this predominance, so that it requires little help from outside for the hot to prevail. And this help is sometimes sufficiently provided by friction, and at other times by fire or one of the naturally hot bodies touching it. It is therefore not at all surprising to say why some things are by nature able to heat our body in return as soon as they touch it, while others do this in a longer time. For among things brought near a fire, some ignite immediately, like a wick, a thin torch, pitch, and a dry reed, while others are not overcome unless they are near it for a long time, like green wood.

But it is more just to distinguish that other matter, the proof of which we shall state in the works *On the Natural Faculties*; but for the sake of the present discussion, we shall use it now hypothetically, stating that there are four proper faculties of every body: one, the attractive faculty for what is proper to it; a second, the retentive faculty for these same things; a third, the alterative; and fourth, after these, the expulsive faculty for what is foreign. And these same faculties belong to the whole substance of each body, which we say is a mixture of hot, cold, dry, and moist. But whenever a body alters a neighboring body according to any single one of the qualities within it, one must not suppose either that its whole substance is then acting, or that the thing being altered can be assimilated; so that nothing that alters in this way could ever be nourished by what is so altered. But if that body were to alter—that is, to act with its whole substance—it would thus assimilate the other to itself, and be nourished by what was altered. For nutrition is nothing other than complete assimilation.

paragraphs.content: Ἐπειδὴ δὲ τοῦτο διώρισται, πάλιν ἐκεῖθεν ἀρκτέον τοῦ λόγου. τῶν ζώων ἕκαστον οἰκείαις τρέφεται τροφαῖς· οἰκεία δ’ ἐστὶν ἑκάστῳ τροφὴ, πᾶν ὅ τι ἂν ἐξομοιωθῆναι δύνηται τῷ τρεφομένῳ σώματι. χρὴ τοίνυν ὅλην τὴν οὐσίαν τοῦ τρέφοντος ὅλῃ τῇ τοῦ τρεφομένου φύσει κοινωνίαν τέ τινα καὶ ὁμοιότητα κεκτῆσθαι, πάντως οὐκ ὀλίγης οὐδ’ ἐνταῦθα τῆς κατὰ τὸ μᾶλλόν τε καὶ ἧττον ὑπαρχούσης ἐν αὐτοῖς διαφορᾶς. τὰ μὲν γὰρ μᾶλλον οἰκεῖά τέ ἐστι καὶ ὅμοια, τὰ δ’ ἧττον, ὥστε καὶ τῆς κατεργασίας τὰ μὲν ἰσχυροτέρας τε καὶ πολυχρονιωτέρας, τὰ δ’ ἀσθενεστέρας τε ἅμα καὶ ὀλιγοχρονιωτέρας προσδεῖται. τὸ μὲν οὖν ὀρνίθειον κρέας ἐλάττονος, τὸ δὲ χοίρειον πλείονος, τὸ δὲ βόειον ἔτι πλείονος. ἐλαχίστης δὲ δεῖται μεταβολῆς εἰς ἐξομοίωσιν οἶνος, ὅθεν καὶ τρέφει, καὶ ῥώννυσι τάχιστα. πάντως μὲν οὖν καὶ τοῦτον ὁμιλῆσαι χρὴ τοῖς πεπτικοῖς ὀργάνοις, γαστρί τε καὶ ἥπατι καὶ φλεψὶν, ἐν οἶς προκατεργασθεὶς τρέφειν ἤδη δύναται τὸ σῶμα· πρὶν δὲ τῆς ἐν τούτοις μεταβολῆς ἐπιτυχεῖν, οὐχ οἷόν τ’ αὐτὸν τροφὴν ζώου γενέσθαι, κᾂν εἰ δι’ ὅλης ἡμέρας καὶ νυκτὸς ἐπικείμενος ἔξωθεν εἴη τῷ σώματι. πολὺ δέ τι μᾶλλον ἄρτος ἔξωθεν ἐπικείμενος, ἢ τεῦτλον, ἢ μάζα, τρέφειν ἀδύνατον. τὰ μὲν οὖν ὁμοιούμενα πάντῃ τροφαί· τὰ δ’ ἄλλα σύμπαντα φάρμακα καλεῖται. διττὴ δὲ καὶ τούτων ἡ φύσις. ἢ γὰρ οἷα προσελήφθη διαμένοντα, νικᾷ καὶ μεταβάλλει τὸ σῶμα, καθ’ ὃν τρόπον ἐκεῖνο τὰ σιτία, καὶ ταῦτα πάντως φάρμακα δηλητήριά τε καὶ φθαρτικὰ τῆς τοῦ ζώου φύσεώς ἐστιν· ἢ μεταβολῆς ἀρχὴν παρὰ τοῦ σώματος λαβόντα, σήπεται τοὐντεῦθεν ἤδη καὶ διαφθείρεται, κἄπειτα συνδιαφθείρει τε καὶ σήπει τὸ σῶμα. δηλητήρια δέ ἐστιν ἔτι καὶ ταῦτα. τρίτον δ’ ἐστὶν ἐπ’ αὐτοῖς εἶδος φαρμάκων, τῶν ἀντιθερμαινόντων μὲν τὸ σῶμα, κακὸν δ’ οὐδὲν ἐργαζομένων. καὶ τέταρτον, ὅσα καὶ ποιοῦντά τι, καὶ πάσχοντα, νικᾶται τῷ χρόνῳ, καὶ τελέως ἐξομοιοῦται. συμπέπτωκε δὲ καὶ τούτοις, ἅμα τε φαρμάκοις εἷναι καὶ τροφαῖς. θαυμαστὸν δ’ οὐδὲν, εἰ βραχείας ἀφορμῆς ἔνια λαβόμενα μεγίστην ἐκτροπὴν ἴσχει τῆς ἀρχαίας φύσεως. ὁρᾶται γοῦν καὶ τῶν ἔξω πολλὰ τοιαῦτα. κατὰ μὲν γὰρ τὴν ἐπὶ τῆς Ἀσίας Μυσίαν οἰκία ποτὲ κατεκαύθη τρόπῳ τοιῷδε. κόπρος ἀπέκειτο περιστερῶν, ἤδη σεσηπυῖα, καὶ τεθερμασμένη, καὶ ἀτμὸν ἀναπέμπουσα, καὶ ἁπτομένοις ἱκανῶς θερμή. ταύτης δὲ πλησίον ἦν, ὡς καὶ ψαύειν ἤδη, θυρὶς ἔχουσα ξύλα νεωστὶ καταληλιμμένα ῥητίνῃ πολλῇ. θέρους οὖν μέσου λάβρος ἥλιος προσβαλὼν, ἐξῆψε τὴν ῥητίνην τε καὶ τὰ ξύλα. κᾀντεῦθεν ἤδη θύραι τινὲς ἕτεραι πλησίον ὑπάρχουσαι καὶ θυρίδες ἔναγχος ἐξαληλιμμέναι ῥητίνῃ ῥᾳδίως διεδέξαντο τὸ πῦρ, καὶ μέχρι τῆς ὀροφῆς ἐξέτειναν. ἐπεὶ δ’ ἅπαξ ἡ φλὸξ ἐκείνης ἐλάβετο, ταχέως ἐπὶ πᾶσαν ἐνεμήθη τὴν οἰκίαν. οὕτω δή πως, οἶμαι, καὶ τὸν Ἀρχιμήδην φασὶ διὰ τῶν πυρίων ἐμπρῆσαι τὰς τῶν πολεμίων τριήρεις. ἀνάπτεται δ’ ἑτοίμως ὑπὸ πυρείου καὶ ἔριον, καὶ στυππεῖον, καὶ θρυαλλὶς, καὶ νάρθηξ, καὶ πᾶν ὅ τι ἂν ὁμοίως ᾖ ξηρὸν καὶ χαῦνον. ἐξάπτουσι δὲ φλόγα καὶ λίθοι παρατριβόμενοι, καὶ μᾶλλον ἂν θείου τις αὐτοῖς ἐπιπάσσῃ. καὶ τὸ τῆς Μηδείας δὲ φάρμακον τοιοῦτο ἦν. πάντα γοῦν ἀνάπτεται προσβαλλούσης θερμασίας, οἶς ἂν ἐπαλειφθῇ. σκευάζεται δὲ κᾀκεῖνο διά τε θείου καὶ τῆς, ὑγρᾶς ἀσφάλτου. καὶ μὲν δὴ καὶ ὡς θαυμαστόν τις ἐδείκνυ· ἀποσβεννὺς λύχνον, αὖθις ἧπτε, τοίχῳ προσφέρων· ἕτερος δὲ λίθῳ προσέφερεν· ἐτεθείωτο δὲ ἄρα καὶ ὁ τοῖχος καὶ ὁ λίθος. καὶ ὡς ἐγνώσθη τοῦτο, θαυμαστὸν οὐκέτ’ ἦν τὸ γινόμενον. πάντα οὖν ταῦτα τὰ φάρμακα, θερμὰ μὲν οὔπω τελέως ἐστὶν, ἐπιτηδειότατα μέντοι πρὸς τὸ γενέσθαι θερμά· καὶ διὰ τοῦτο δυνάμει θερμὰ λέγεται. περὶ μὲν δὴ τούτων οὐδὲν ἄπορον. ἀλλ’ οὐδὲ διὰ τί πινόμενος μὲν ὁ οἶνος ἱκανῶς θερμαίνει τὸ σῶμα, κατὰ δὲ τοῦ δέρματος ἐπιτιθέμενος οὐ θερμαίνει. δέδεικται γὰρ ὀλίγῳ πρότερον, οὐχ ἁπλῶς ὥσπερ θερμὸν φάρμακον, ἀλλ’ ὡς οἰκεία τροφὴ, θερμαῖνον τὸ ζῶον. ὡς γὰρ αἱ τοῦ πυρὸς ἐπιτήδειοι τροφαὶ τὸ πῦρ αὔξουσιν, οὕτω καὶ τῶν φύσει θερμῶν σωμάτων ὅ τί περ ἂν οἰκεία τε καὶ σύμφυτος ὑπάρχῃ τροφὴ, ῥώσει τε διὰ παντὸς αὐτὰ, καὶ τὴν ἔμφυτον αὐξήσει θερμασίαν. καὶ τοῦτο μὲν ἁπάσης τροφῆς κοινόν. οἴνῳ δ’ ἴδιον ἐξαίρετον ὑπάρχει τὸ τάχος τῆς μεταβολῆς, ὡς δᾳδὶ, καὶ θρυαλλίδι, καὶ στυππείῳ, καὶ πίττῃ. καὶ δὴ καὶ τῆς εἰκόνος ἐχόμενοι τοῦ πυρὸς, ἀναμνήσομεν αὖθις ξύλων ὑγρῶν, ἃ τροφὴ μέν ἐστι καὶ αὐτὰ τοῦ πυρὸς, ἀλλ’ οὐκ εὐθὺς, οὐδ’ ἐκ τοῦ παραχρῆμα. καὶ διὰ τοῦτο ἐπιβληθέντα πολλὰ τῷ πυρὶ κατακρύπτει τε τὴν φλόγα, καὶ μάλιστ’, ἂν ἀσθενὴς ὑπάρχῃ καὶ σμικρὰ, κίνδυνον ἐπάγει φθορᾶς. οὕτως οὖν κᾀν τοῖς ζώοις, ὅσα τῶν ἐδεσμάτων, ἵν’ ἐξομοιωθῇ τελέως καὶ θρέψῃ τὸ σῶμα, χρόνου δεῖται, ψύχος μᾶλλον ἐπάγειν ἢ θάλπος ἐν τῷ παραχρῆμα φαίνεται. θερμαίνει μὴν ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ καὶ ταῦτα, παραπλησίως τοῖς ἄλλοις ἐδέσμασιν, εἰ μόνον αὐτοῖς προσγένηται τὸ θρέψαι τὸ σῶμα. τροφὴ γὰρ ἅπασα κατὰ τὸν ἑαυτῆς λόγον αὔξει τὸ τοῦ ζώου θερμόν. εἰ δὲ καταποθείη μὲν ὡς τροφὴ, μὴ μέντοι δὲ κρατηθείη, τοῦτ’ ἐκεῖνο τὸ πρὸς Ἱπποκράτους εἰρημένον, εἴη ἂν ὄνομα τροφῆς, ἔργον δ’ οὐχί. τριχῶς γὰρ τῆς τροφῆς λεγομένης, ὥς γε αὐτὸς ἐδίδαξε τοῦτ’ εἰπών· Τροφὴ δὲ τὸ τρέφον, τροφὴ τὸ οἷον τροφὴ, καὶ τὸ μέλλον· ἡ μὲν ἤδη τρέφουσα, καὶ προστιθεμένη, καὶ μηκέτι μέλλουσα, κυρίως ὀνομάζεται τροφὴ καὶ δὴ καὶ θερμαίνει πάντως τὸ τρεφόμενον σῶμα· τῶν δ’ ἄλλων οὐδετέρα, διότι μηδὲ τροφαὶ κυρίως εἰσὶν, ἀλλὰ τὸ μὲν οἷον τροφὴ, τὸ δ’, ὅτι μέλλει τοιοῦτο γενήσεσθαι. ταῦτ’ ἄρα καὶ αὐτὸς ὁ οἶνος οὐκ ἀεὶ θερμαίνει τὸ ζῶον, ὥσπερ οὐδὲ τοὔλαιον ἀνάπτει τὴν φλόγα, καίτοι γ’ οἰκειοτάτη τροφὴ πυρὸς ὑπάρχον. ἀλλ’ ἐὰν ἀσθενεῖ καὶ σμικρᾷ φλογὶ καταχέῃς ἔλαιον ἀθρόον καὶ πολὺ, καταπνίξεις, καὶ τελέως ἀποσβέσεις αὐτὴν μᾶλλον ἢ αὐξήσεις. οὕτως οὖν καὶ ὁ οἶνος, ἐπειδὰν πολὺς, ὡς μὴ κρατεῖσθαι, πίνηται, τοσοῦτον ἀποδεῖ τοῦ θερμαίνειν τὸ ζῶων, ὥστε καὶ πάθη ψυχρότερα γεννᾷ. ἀποπληξίαι γοῦν καὶ παραπληξίαι καὶ κάροι καὶ κώματα καὶ παραλύσεις ἐπιληψίαι τε καὶ σπασμοὶ καὶ τέτανοι ταῖς ἀμέτροις οἴνου πόσεσιν ἕπονται, ψυχρὰ σύμπαντα πάθη. καθόλου γὰρ, ὅσα τῶν εἰς τὸ σῶμα λαμβανομένων ὡς τροφὴ θερμαίνει, ταῦθ’ εὕροις ἄν ποτε ψύχοντα, καθ’ ὅ τι καὶ τὴν φλόγα πρὸς τῆς αὐτῆς ὕλης οὐκ αὐξανομένην μόνον, ἀλλὰ καὶ σβεννυμένην ἐνίοτε. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν ἔοικεν ὁμολογεῖν ἅπαντα τοῖς τε περὶ στοιχείων καὶ τοῖς περὶ κράσεων λογισμοῖς.
paragraphs.openai_translation: Since this has been determined, we must again take our argument from that point. Each animal is nourished by foods proper to it; and “proper” food for each is whatever is able to be assimilated to the body that is nourished. Accordingly, the entire substance of what nourishes must have with the entire nature of what is nourished a certain community and likeness, though here too there is by all means no small difference in the “more and less” that belongs to them. For some things are more proper and similar, others less; and so in their processing some require stronger and more prolonged workmanship [i.e., digestion], others weaker and shorter. Thus bird-flesh needs less, pork more, and beef still more. Wine needs the least change for assimilation, whence it both nourishes and very quickly invigorates. Nevertheless, even it must associate with the peptic organs—the stomach, the liver, and the veins—in which, having first been worked upon, it can then nourish the body; before it undergoes change in these, it is not possible for it to become an animal’s food, even if it were laid upon the body from outside all day and night. Much less could bread laid upon the outside, or beet, or a barley-cake, nourish. So then, whatever things are in every way assimilated are foods; all the rest in general are called drugs [pharmaka]. And these too are twofold in kind. For either, remaining as they were when taken in, they overcome and alter the body—in the same way as the latter changes ordinary foods—and these are certainly drugs, poisons and destructive of an animal’s nature; or else, having taken the beginning of change from the body, they then rot and are corrupted, and thereafter corrupt and rot the body along with them. These too are poisons. There is a third kind among drugs: those which heat the body in reaction, yet work no harm. And a fourth: those which, while both acting and being acted upon, are overcome with time and are completely assimilated. It also happens with these that they are at once drugs and foods. Nor is it any wonder if some things, taking only a slight starting impulse, undergo a very great deviation from their original nature. Indeed, many such cases are observed even among external things. For in Mysia of Asia a house was once burned down in this way. There lay pigeon-dung, already rotted and warmed and sending up vapor, and hot enough to the touch; and close to it—indeed within reach—there was a small window whose wood had been freshly smeared with much resin. When then in the middle of summer a blazing sun struck upon it, he kindled both the resin and the wood. From there other doors and windows nearby, just lately smeared with resin, readily caught the fire and carried it up to the roof; and once the flame took hold of that, it quickly spread over the whole house. In just this way, I think, they also say that Archimedes set the enemy triremes ablaze by means of burning mirrors [burning-glasses]. Wool, tow, a wick, a giant-fennel stalk, and anything likewise dry and porous are readily kindled by a burning-glass. Sparks are also struck by rubbing stones together, and still more if one dusts them with sulfur. Such too was Medea’s drug. For everything to which it was smeared would be kindled when heat struck it. And that compound was prepared with sulfur and liquid bitumen [naphtha]. Indeed, someone even displayed it as a marvel: after snuffing out a lamp, he lit it again by bringing it up to a wall; another lit it by bringing it up to a stone—the wall and the stone, it turned out, had been sulfur-smeared. And once this was understood, what happened was no longer a marvel. All such drugs are not yet actually hot, but are most apt to become hot; therefore they are said to be hot in potency. About these, then, there is no difficulty, nor about why wine, when drunk, sufficiently warms the body, but when applied upon the skin does not warm. For it was shown a little earlier that it warms the living being not simply as a hot drug, but as a proper food. For as suitable fuels feed a fire, so whatever food is by nature proper and connatural to warm bodies will continuously refresh them and increase their innate heat. This is common to all food. Wine, however, has a special property: the speed of its change [i.e., assimilation], like torch-wood, wick, tow, and pitch. And keeping to the image of fire, let us recall damp wood: this too is fuel for fire, but not immediately, not at once; and for that reason, when a great deal of it is thrown on a fire, it smothers the flame and—especially if the flame is weak and small—brings the risk of its extinction. So too in animals, those foods which require time in order to be fully assimilated and nourish the body appear to bring on cold rather than heat at the moment. Yet in the long run they warm as well, in a way like other foods, if only the additional condition is met—that they actually nourish the body. For every food, by its own account, increases the animal’s heat. But if something is swallowed as food yet is not mastered [i.e., not assimilated], then we have what Hippocrates spoke of: it would be “food in name, not in deed.” For since “food” is said in a threefold way, as he himself taught when he said, “Food is that which nourishes; food is that which is like food; and that which is going to be [food],” the one that already nourishes—being added and no longer future—is properly called “food,” and it certainly warms the body that is nourished; of the other two, neither does, because they are not properly foods, but the one is “like food,” and the other is “what is going to become such.” Therefore even wine itself does not always warm the living being—just as oil does not always kindle a flame, though it is the most proper fuel for fire. If you pour oil in a mass and in quantity upon a weak, small flame, you will smother and completely extinguish it rather than increase it. So too with wine: whenever it is drunk in such quantity that it is not mastered, it so far is from warming the living being that it even produces colder affections. Apoplexies, paralytic stupors, deep lethargies, palsies, epilepsies, convulsions, and tetani follow upon immoderate drinking of wine—affections all of them cold. In general, whatever of the things taken into the body warms as food, you will find it at some time cooling—just as with the same material a flame is not only increased but is sometimes even quenched. All these points, then, seem to agree with the reasonings concerning the elements and concerning mixtures [kraseis, temperaments].
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Since this has been determined, we must begin our discussion again from that point. Each animal is nourished by its proper foods; and proper food for each is whatever can be assimilated to the body being nourished. Therefore, the entire substance of the nourishing material must possess some community and similarity with the entire nature of what is nourished, though certainly here too there exists no small difference in degree of more and less among them. For some things are more proper and similar, others less so, so that some require stronger and more prolonged processing, while others need weaker and shorter processing. Chicken meat requires less, pork more, and beef still more. Wine requires the least transformation for assimilation, which is why it both nourishes and strengthens most quickly.

Indeed, even wine must interact with the digestive organs—stomach, liver, and veins—in which, after being processed, it can then nourish the body. But before achieving transformation in these organs, it cannot become food for an animal, even if it were applied externally to the body for an entire day and night. Much more so is bread, or beet, or barley cake unable to nourish when applied externally. Therefore, things that are completely assimilated are foods; all others are called drugs. The nature of these too is twofold. For either they remain as they were taken in, overcoming and changing the body in the way the body changes foods—and these are certainly poisonous drugs destructive to the animal's nature—or, receiving the beginning of change from the body, they subsequently putrefy and are destroyed, and then jointly destroy and putrefy the body. These too are poisons.

There is a third type of drugs beyond these, which warm the body but cause no harm. And a fourth type: those which both act and are acted upon, are overcome in time, and are completely assimilated. It happens that these are both drugs and foods. It is not surprising if some things, taking a small starting point, undergo the greatest deviation from their original nature. For many such things are observed externally. In Mysia in Asia, a house once burned down in the following way. Pigeon dung was stored, already putrefied and heated, giving off vapor and quite warm to the touch. Near this, close enough to touch, was a window frame with wood recently smeared with much resin. In midsummer, the fierce sun striking it ignited the resin and the wood. From there, other nearby doors and window frames recently smeared with resin easily caught the fire and extended it to the roof. Once the flame seized that, it quickly spread through the entire house.

In this way, I think, they say Archimedes set fire to enemy triremes using burning-mirrors. Wool, tow, wick-material, fennel-stalk, and anything similarly dry and porous readily ignites from a burning-glass. Stones rubbed together also produce flame, especially if one sprinkles sulfur on them. Medea's drug was of this type—everything ignites when heat is applied to whatever has been smeared with it. That too is prepared from sulfur and liquid asphalt. Indeed, someone demonstrated something remarkable: extinguishing a lamp, he relit it by bringing it to a wall; another brought it to a stone. Both the wall and stone had been treated with sulfur. Once this was understood, the phenomenon was no longer remarkable.

All these drugs are not yet completely hot, but are most suited to becoming hot; therefore they are called potentially hot. About these there is no difficulty. Nor is there difficulty about why wine drunk heats the body considerably, but applied to the skin does not heat it. For it was shown a little earlier that it heats the animal not simply as a hot drug, but as proper food. For just as suitable fuel for fire increases the fire, so whatever is proper and natural food for naturally hot bodies will always strengthen them and increase their innate heat. This is common to all food. But wine has the exceptional property of speed of transformation, like a torch, wick, tow, or pitch.

Holding to the image of fire, we recall again wet wood, which is also fuel for fire, but not immediately or instantly. Therefore, when much is thrown on the fire, it both conceals the flame and, especially if it is weak and small, brings danger of extinction. Thus in animals too, those foods which require time to be completely assimilated and nourish the body appear to bring cold rather than warmth immediately. Yet these too warm in time, similarly to other foods, if only they succeed in nourishing the body. For all food according to its own nature increases the animal's heat.

But if something is consumed as food yet not mastered, this would be what Hippocrates said: the name of food but not the function. For since food is spoken of in three ways, as he himself taught by saying "Food is what nourishes, food is what is like food, and what will be"—that which is already nourishing and being added and no longer future is properly called food and certainly warms the nourished body. But neither of the others does, because they are not properly foods, but one is "like food," the other because it will become such.

Therefore wine itself does not always warm the animal, just as oil does not ignite flame, though it is most proper fuel for fire. But if you pour oil abundantly and in quantity on a weak and small flame, you will smother and completely extinguish it rather than increase it. Thus wine too, when drunk in such quantity that it cannot be mastered, is so far from warming the animal that it produces colder conditions. For apoplexy, paralysis, stupor, coma, palsy, epilepsy, convulsions, and tetanus follow immoderate wine drinking—all cold conditions. In general, you would find that whatever taken into the body warms as food sometimes cools, just as flame is not only increased but sometimes extinguished by the same material. These things seem to agree entirely with the theories about elements and about mixtures.
paragraphs.gemini_translation:
**Paragraph 2:**

Now that this has been determined, we must begin the argument again from that point. Each animal is nourished by its own proper foods; and a proper food for each is whatever can be assimilated by the body being nourished. The entire substance of the nutrient must therefore possess a certain affinity and similarity to the entire nature of the body being nourished, although there is certainly no small difference of degree among them in this respect as well. For some things are more proper and similar, and others less so, with the result that some require a stronger and more prolonged processing, while others need one that is weaker and shorter. Thus, the meat of birds requires less processing, that of pigs more, and that of cattle still more. Wine, however, requires the least change for assimilation, for which reason it both nourishes and invigorates most quickly. To be sure, wine too must interact with the digestive organs—the stomach, liver, and veins—in which, having been pre-processed, it can then nourish the body. But before it undergoes the change within these organs, it is not possible for it to become nourishment for an animal, even if it were applied to the outside of the body for a whole day and night. And it is much more impossible for bread, or beet, or barley-cake to provide nourishment when applied externally.

Therefore, things that are completely assimilated are foods; all other things are called drugs [pharmaka]. And the nature of these drugs is twofold. For either, remaining as they were taken in, they overcome and alter the body in the same way that the body alters foods—and these are in every case poisonous drugs, destructive to the animal's nature; or, receiving the beginning of a change from the body, they thereupon putrefy and are corrupted, and then they corrupt and cause the body to putrefy along with them. And these too are poisons. And there is a third class of drugs besides these: those that heat the body in turn but do no harm. And a fourth: those which, while both acting and being acted upon, are overcome in time and are completely assimilated. It is the case for these that they are at once both drugs and foods.

And it is not at all surprising if some things, by taking hold of a small starting-point, undergo a very great deviation from their original nature. At any rate, many such things are seen even in the external world. For in Mysia in Asia, a house once burned down in the following way. A pile of pigeon dung lay there, already putrefied, heated, and giving off vapor, and quite warm to the touch. Near this, so close as to be touching it, was a window-shutter with wood freshly smeared with much resin. It was the middle of summer, and a fierce sun, beating down upon it, ignited the resin and the wood. And from there, some other doors and shutters nearby, which had also been recently smeared with resin, easily caught the fire in turn and extended it up to the roof. And once the flame took hold of that, it quickly spread over the whole house. It was in some such way, I believe, that they say Archimedes set fire to the enemy's triremes with his burning-glasses. Wool, tow, a lamp-wick, and a fennel-stalk are also readily kindled by a burning-glass, as is anything that is similarly dry and porous. Stones, too, when rubbed against each other, ignite a flame, especially if one sprinkles some sulfur on them. And Medea's drug was of such a kind; at any rate, it ignites whatever it is smeared on when heat is applied. That drug is also prepared with both sulfur and liquid bitumen. Indeed, someone once demonstrated a marvel: extinguishing a lamp, he lit it again by bringing it to a wall; another did so by bringing it to a stone. It turned out that both the wall and the stone had been treated with sulfur. And when this was known, the event was no longer a marvel. All these drugs, therefore, are not yet actually hot, but are most suitable for becoming hot; and for this reason they are said to be potentially hot [dynamei therma].

Concerning these matters, then, there is no difficulty. Nor is there any difficulty as to why wine, when drunk, sufficiently heats the body, but when applied to the skin, does not heat it. For it was shown a little earlier that it heats the animal not simply like a hot drug, but as a proper food. For just as the suitable foods of a fire make the fire grow, so too for naturally hot bodies, whatever is a proper and congenital food will always strengthen them and increase their innate heat. And this is common to all food. But wine has the special, exceptional quality of speed of transformation, like a torch, a wick, tow, and pitch. And indeed, holding to the image of fire, we will call to mind again wet wood, which is also food for the fire, but not immediately or instantly. For this reason, when a lot of it is thrown on a fire, it hides the flame, and especially if the fire is weak and small, it brings the danger of extinction. So too in animals, whatever foods require time to be completely assimilated and to nourish the body, appear to bring on cold rather than warmth in the immediate moment. Yet in time these too produce heat, just like other foods, if only they succeed in nourishing the body. For all food, in accordance with its own nature, increases the heat of the animal. But if it should be swallowed as food, but not be mastered by the body, this would be that which was spoken of by Hippocrates: "it would have the name of food, but not the reality." For since nourishment is spoken of in three ways, as he himself taught when he said, "Nourishment is that which nourishes, nourishment is that which is like nourishment, and that which is going to be," the one that is already nourishing and being added to the body, and is no longer "going to be," is called nourishment in the proper sense, and it certainly heats the body being nourished. But neither of the others is, because they are not nourishment in the proper sense, but one is "like nourishment," and the other is so called because it is "going to be" such.

For these reasons, then, wine itself does not always heat the animal, just as oil does not always kindle a flame, even though it is a most proper food for fire. But if you pour a great quantity of oil all at once on a weak and small flame, you will smother and completely extinguish it rather than make it grow. So too with wine, when so much is drunk that it cannot be mastered, it is so far from heating the animal that it even generates colder affections. At any rate, apoplexies, paraplexies, stupors, comas, paralyses, epilepsies, spasms, and tetanus—all cold affections—follow upon immoderate consumption of wine. For in general, whatever things taken into the body as food are heating, you would find that these sometimes have a cooling effect, in the same way that a flame is not only increased by the same matter, but sometimes even extinguished by it. All these things, then, seem to agree with the reasonings concerning both the elements and the mixtures [kraseis].

paragraphs.content: Ἐκεῖνο δ’ ἂν ἴσως δόξειε διαφέρεσθαι, τό τινα τῶν ἐσθιομένων ἐν τροφῆς χρείᾳ, κατὰ τοῦ δέρματος ἐπιτιθέμενα, διαβιβρώσκειν τε καὶ ἑλκοῦν αὐτὸ, καθάπερ νάπυ καὶ τάριχος, σκόροδά τε καὶ κρόμμυα. καίτοι τοῦτο συμφωνεῖ τοῖς ἐξ ἀρχῆς ὑποκειμένοις· ἅμα μὲν γὰρ, ὅτι μεταβάλλεται καὶ ἀλλοιοῦται κατά τε τὴν γαστέρα πεπτόμενα, κᾀν ταῖς φλεψὶν αἱματούμενα· πρὸς δὲ τούτοις, καὶ διότι μὴ μένει καθ’ ἕνα τόπον, ἀλλ’ εἰς πολλὰ μερίζεται πάντῃ φερόμενα· καὶ πρὸς τούτοις, διότι μίγνυται καὶ χυμοῖς πολλοῖς, καὶ τοῖς ἅμα αὐτοῖς λαμβανομένοις σιτίοις· ἔτι δὲ πρὸς τούτοις, ὅτι διὰ ταχέων ἥ τε πέψις αὐτῶν γίνεται, καὶ ἡ διάκρισις, ὡς τὸ μὲν οἰκεῖον ἐξομοιωθῆναι, τὸ δὲ περιττὸν ἐν αὐτοῖς καὶ δριμὺ διὰ γαστρός τε ἅμα καὶ οὔρων καὶ ἱδρώτων ἐκκριθῆναι, διὰ ταῦτα πάντα τὸ ἔξωθεν ἑλκοῦν, ἐσθιόμενον οὐχ ἑλκοῖ. καίτοι κᾂν τῶν εἰρημένων ἓν ὁτιοῦν ὑπῆρχεν αὐτοῖς, ἱκανὸν ἂν ἦν δήπουθεν ἀβλαβῆ φυλάξαι τὰ ἐκτὸς, οἶον, εἰ τύχοι, τὸ μεταβάλλειν πρῶτον. εἰ γὰρ οὐ μένει τὸ νάπυ τοιοῦτο, οἶον ἔξωθεν ἐλήφθη, δῆλον ὡς οὐδὲ τὴν δύναμιν αὐτοῦ μένειν ἀξιώσεις. εἰ δὲ καὶ διακρίνεται καὶ καθαίρεται, πολὺ δὴ καὶ μᾶλλον. ἤρκει δὲ καὶ τὸ μὴ χρονίζειν ἐν ἑνὶ χωρίῳ. φαίνεται γὰρ οὐδὲ περὶ τὸ δέρμα δρᾶσαί τι δυνάμενον ἄνευ χρόνου πλείονος. ἀλλὰ καὶ τὸ μίγνυσθαι πολλοῖς ἑτέροις σιτίοις οὐ σμικρὸν οὐδ’ αὐτό. γνοίης δ’ ἂν, εἰ μόνον αὐτὸ προσενέγκοις χωρὶς τῶν ἄλλων σιτίων, ὅσην ἀνίαν τε καὶ δῆξιν ἐπιφέρει τῇ γαστρί. καὶ μὲν δὴ, κᾂν εἰ πολλοῖς γλυκέσι χυμοῖς ἀναμίξας αὐτὸ κατὰ τοῦ δέρματος ἐπιθείης, οὐδὲν ἐργάσεται φαῦλον. ὁπότε οὖν ἕκαστον τῶν εἰρημένων ἱκανόν ἐστι καθ’ αὑτὸ κωλῦσαι τὸ νάπυ δρᾶσαί τι τοιοῦτο ἐντὸς, οἷον ἐκτὸς ἔδρα περὶ τὸ δέρμα, πολὺ δή που μᾶλλον, οἶμαι, πάντων ἅμα συνελθόντων. καὶ γὰρ ἀλλοιοῦται πεπτόμενον, καὶ διακρίνεται, καὶ καθαίρεται, καὶ πολλοῖς ἑτέροις ἀναμίγνυται, καὶ μερίζεται πολλαχῶς, καὶ πανταχῇ φέρεται, καὶ χρονίζει κατ’ οὐδὲν τῶν μορίων. ὅτι δ’, εἴπερ ἔμενε δριμὺ, πάντως ἂν ἥλκωσε καὶ τὰ ἐντὸς, ἐκ τῶν αὐτομάτων ἑλκῶν ἐπιγνώσῃ. γίνεται γὰρ πολλοῖς πολλάκις, τοῖς μὲν ἐξ ἐδεσμάτων μοχθηρῶν, τοῖς δ’ ἔκ τινος ἐν αὐτῷ τῷ σώματι διαφθορᾶς καὶ σηπεδόνος ἡ καλουμένη κακοχυμία. καὶ τούτοις ἐνίοτε μὲν ἑλκοῦταί τι καὶ τῶν ἐντός· ὡς τὰ πολλὰ δὲ καὶ τῷ τὴν φύσιν ἀποτρίβεσθαι τὰ κατὰ τὴν ἕξιν περιττώματα πρὸς τὸ δέρμα, τοῦθ’ ἑλκοῦται πολλοῖς καὶ συνεχέσιν ἕλκεσι. καρκῖνός τε γὰρ, καὶ φαγέδαινα, καὶ ἕρπης ὁ ἀναβιβρωσκόμενος, ἄνθρακές τε καὶ τὰ χειρώνεια καὶ τηλέφεια καλούμενα, καὶ ἄλλαι μυρίαι γενέσεις ἑλκῶν ἔκγονοι τῆς τοιαύτης εἰσὶ κακοχυμίας. οὔτ’ οὖν τῶν τοιούτων οὐδὲν ἄπορον, οὔτε διὰ τί τῶν φαρμάκων ἔνια μὲν ἡμᾶς οὐδὲν ἔξωθεν ἀδικοῦντα, μέγα τι κακὸν ἐργάζεται καταποθέντα· τινὰ δὲ πολλάκις ἔβλαψεν εἴσω ληφθέντα, πολλάκις δὲ ὠφέλησεν· ἔνια δὲ οὐ μόνον ἔσωθεν, ἀλλὰ καὶ ἔξωθεν ἀδικεῖ. συλλήβδην γοῦν εἰπεῖν, οὐδὲν ὁμοίως ἔσωθέν τε καὶ ἔξωθεν ἐνεργεῖν πέφυκεν. οὔτε γὰρ ὁ τοῦ λυττῶντος κυνὸς ἀφρὸς, οὔθ’ ὁ τῆς ἀσπίδος, οὔθ’ ὁ τῆς ἐχίδνης ἰὸς, οἳ δὴ καὶ χωρὶς ἕλκους ἔξωθεν προσπεσόντες ἀδικεῖν πεπίστευνται, τὴν ἴσην ἔχουσι δύναμιν, ἢ τῷ δέρματι μόνῳ προσομιλήσαντες, ἢ εἴσω μεταληφθέντες. οὐ μὴν οὐδ’ ἐκεῖνο θαυμάζειν ἄξιον, εἴ τινων φαρμάκων οὐκ ἐξικνεῖται πρὸς τὸ βάθος ἡ δύναμις· οὐ γὰρ ἀναγκαῖον ἅπαντα τὴν αὐτὴν ἔχειν ἰσχύν. εἰ δὲ πολλὰ τῶν εἴσω λαμβανομένων ἐν μὲν τῷδε τῷ καιρῷ, καὶ μετὰ τοσῆσδε ποσότητος, καὶ τῆς πρὸς τάδε μίξεως, ὠφέλησεν, ἀκαίρως δὲ, καὶ πολλὰ, καὶ ἄμικτα ληφθέντα, βλάβην ἤνεγκεν, οὐδὲν ἐντεῦθεν ἀπόρημα τῷ λόγῳ. καὶ γὰρ καὶ τοῖς σιτίοις ὑπάρχει τοῦτό γε, καὶ τῷ πυρὶ, καὶ πᾶσιν ὡσαύτως φάναι τοῖς προσπίπτουσι τῷ σώματι. συμμέτρου γοῦν φλογὸς ἔστιν ὅτε δεόμεθα, καὶ χρώμενοι μεγάλα πρὸς αὐτῆς ὀνινάμεθα, καίτοι τῆς ἀμέτρου καιούσης ἡμᾶς. οὕτω δὲ καὶ ψυχροῦ πόσις ἡ μὲν σύμμετρος ὀνίνησιν, ἡ δὲ ἄμετρος ἐσχάτως βλάπτει. τί τοίνυν θαυμαστὸν, εἶναί τι φάρμακον οὕτω δυνάμει θερμὸν, ὡς, εἰ μὲν πολύ τε λαμβάνοιτο καὶ κενῷ τῷ σώματι προσφέροιτο, διαβιβρώσκειν τε καὶ καίειν αὐτὸ παντελῶς, εἰ δ’ ὀλίγον εἴη ἢ καὶ σὺν τοῖς κολάζουσιν τὴν ἰσχὺν αὐτοῦ, πρὸς τῷ μὴ βλάπτειν μηδὲν, ἔτι καὶ θερμαῖνον ὠφελεῖν; ὀπὸν γοῦν, ἤτοι τὸν Κυρηναικὸν, ἢ τὸν Μηδικὸν, ἢ τὸν Παρθικὸν, αὐτὸν καθ’ αὑτὸν οὐκ ἔστιν ἀλύπως λαβεῖν· ἀλλ’ εἰ παντελῶς ὀλίγος, ἢ σὺν ἄλλοις ἐν καιρῷ τῷ προσήκοντι ληφθείη, μεγάλως ὠφελεῖ. ταύτῃ μὲν οὖν, ὅσα θερμαίνει τὸ σῶμα, μεταβολῆς ἀρχὴν ἐν αὐτῷ λαβόντα, καθότι πρόσθεν ἐῤῥέθη, πάλιν ἀντιθερμαίνειν αὐτὸ πέφυκεν· ὅσα δὲ ψύχει, καθάπερ ὀπὸς μήκωνος, οὐ μεταβάλλεται πρὸς τοῦ σώματος οὐδ’ ἐπ’ ὀλίγον, ἀλλ’ εὐθὺς αὐτὸ νικᾷ καὶ μεταβάλλει, κᾂν εἰ θερμῄνας αὐτὰ δοίης. ἔστι γὰρ ἡ σφῶν αὐτῶν φύσις ψυχρὰ, καθότι καὶ τὸ ὕδωρ. ὀρθῶς οὖν καὶ τοῦτο σὺν πολλοῖς ἄλλοις ὑπ’ Ἀριστοτέλους εἴρηται, τὸ τῶν θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν καὶ ξηρῶν καὶ ὑγρῶν σωμάτων τὰ μὲν εἶναι καθ’ αὑτὰ τοιαῦτα, τὰ δὲ κατὰ συμβεβηκός. οἷον καὶ τὸ ὕδωρ καθ’ αὑτὸ μὲν ψυχρὸν, κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς δέ ποτε θερμόν. ἀλλ’ ἡ μὲν ἐπίκτητος αὐτοῦ θερμασία ταχέως ἀπόλλυται, μένει δ’ ἡ σύμφυτος ψυχρότης. ὡς οὖν ὕδωρ θερμὸν ἐπιβληθὲν φλογὶ, κατασβέννυσιν αὐτὴν, οὕτω καὶ τὸ μηκώνειον εἰ καὶ ὅτι μάλιστα θερμῄνας δοίης, ἀποψύξεις τε τὴν ἐν τοῖς ζώοις θερμασίαν, καὶ κίνδυνον ἐπάξεις θανάτου. πάντα οὖν τὰ τοιαῦτα φάρμακα, βραχέα τε διδόμενα καὶ σὺν τοῖς κολάζειν αὐτῶν τὸ σφοδρὸν τῆς ψύξεως δυναμένοις, ἔστιν ὅτε χρείαν τινὰ παρέχει τοῖς σώμασιν ἡμῶν, ὡς ἐν τοῖς περὶ φαρμάκων εἰρήσεται. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ τὸ διὰ τῶν κανθαρίδων φάρμακον ἱκανῶς ὀνίνησι τοὺς ὑδερικοὺς, καίτοι τοὐπίπαν ἑλκοῖ τὴν κύστιν ἡ κανθαρίς· ἀλλ’ ἐπειδὰν ὑπό τε τῶν μιχθέντων αὐτῇ κολασθῇ, καὶ σώματι προσάγηται παμπόλλην ὑγρότητα περιέχοντι, κενοῖ διὰ τῶν οὔρων αὐτήν. μάλιστα οὖν χρὴ προσέχειν τὸν νοῦν ἐν ἅπασι τοῖς δυνάμει θερμοῖς ἢ ψυχροῖς εἶναι λεγομένοις, εἴτε τῆς φύσεώς ἐστι τῶν τρέφειν δυναμένων, εἴτε μόνην ἀφορμὴν ἀλλοιώσεως λαμβάνοντα, κᾄπειτα κατὰ τὴν οἰκείαν φύσιν ἀλλοιούμενα, διατίθησί πως τὸ σῶμα, καὶ τρίτον ἐπὶ τούτοις, εἰ μηδ’ ὅλως ἀλλοιοῦται πρὸς αὐτοῦ κατὰ μηδέν. εἰ μὲν γὰρ ἐκ τοῦ γένους εἴη τῶν τρεφόντων, εἰ μὲν κρατηθείη, θερμαίνει, μὴ κρατηθέντα δὲ, ψύχει· εἰ δὲ τῶν ἐπ’ ὀλίγον ποσὸν ἀλλοιουμένων, θερμαίνει πάντως· εἰ δὲ τῶν μηδ’ ὅλως, ψύχει μάλιστα.
paragraphs.openai_translation: That point, perhaps, may seem to differ: that certain things which are eaten, though needed as food, when applied upon the skin, corrode and ulcerate it—like mustard and salted fish, and garlic and onions. And yet this agrees with the principles set down at the start: partly because they are transformed and altered, being digested in the stomach and then becoming blood in the veins; in addition, because they do not remain in one place but are divided up and carried everywhere into many parts; and further, because they are mixed both with many juices [humors] and with the foods taken along with them; and further still, because both their digestion and their separation take place quickly, so that what is akin is assimilated, while the superfluous, sharp part in them is excreted through the stomach and at the same time through urine and sweat. For all these reasons, what ulcerates from without does not ulcerate when eaten. Indeed, even if any one of the points mentioned belonged to them, it would surely be sufficient to keep the external parts unharmed—for instance, if to begin with they happened to change. For if mustard does not remain such as it was when applied externally, it is clear you will not deem that its power remains either. And if it is also separated out and purged away, then all the more so. It would have sufficed too that it not linger in one region. For it appears that nothing capable of acting on the skin does anything without a considerable time. And the fact that it is mixed with many other foods is no small matter either. You would realize this, if you were to administer it alone, apart from the other foods, how much distress and smarting it brings upon the stomach. And indeed, if you were to apply it upon the skin, mixed with many sweet juices, it would do no serious harm. When, therefore, each of the points mentioned is in itself sufficient to prevent mustard from doing inside what it did outside upon the skin, surely much more so, I think, when all of them come together at once. For it is altered in digestion, and it is separated, and it is purged away, and it is mixed with many other things, and it is divided in many ways, and it is carried everywhere, and it lingers in none of the parts. And that, if it did remain sharp, it would certainly ulcerate the internal parts too, you may recognize from spontaneous ulcerations. For it happens often to many—some through bad foods, others through the so‑called dyscrasia arising from some decay and putrefaction in the body itself. In these people at times some of the internal parts ulcerate; but most often, since the superfluities which wear down the nature according to their condition are rubbed off toward the skin, this is what becomes ulcerated in many with frequent and persistent sores. For cancer, and phagedena, and the creeping herpes that eats upward, and carbuncles, and the ulcers called cheironeia and telephia, and countless other kinds of sores, are offspring of such dyscrasia. Thus none of these things is puzzling, nor why some drugs, which do us no harm externally, produce great evil when swallowed; while some, when taken internally, have at times harmed and at times helped; and some do harm not only internally but also externally. In a word, nothing by nature acts in the same way from within and from without. For neither the foam of a rabid dog nor the poison of the asp nor that of the viper—things believed to harm even when they fall upon us externally without a wound—have the same power when they merely touch the skin as when taken within. Nor, indeed, is it worthy of wonder if the power of certain drugs does not reach in depth; it is not necessary that all have the same strength. And if many things taken inwardly, at one time—at such‑and‑such a moment, and with such a quantity, and in mixture with such things—have helped, but when taken at the wrong time, and in large amounts, and unmixed, have caused harm, there is no difficulty in the reasoning on that account. For this holds also of foods, and of fire, and likewise of all things that affect the body. For there are times when we need a moderate flame, and by using it we gain great benefit from it, although an immoderate one burns us. So too the drinking of cold—when moderate—benefits, but when immoderate harms most severely. What, then, is surprising if there is some drug hot in power to such a degree that, if much of it were taken and offered to a body that is empty, it would corrode and utterly burn it, but if it were little, or given together with things that restrain its strength, then, besides doing no harm, it would even help by warming? For the sap [latex]—whether the Cyrenaic, or the Median, or the Parthian—cannot be taken by itself without pain; but if it be taken in a very small amount, or together with other things at the suitable time, it greatly helps. In this way, then, whatever warms the body, having received in it a starting‑point of change, as was said before, is naturally disposed to be warmed in return by it again; but whatever cools—like the latex of the poppy [opium]—is not changed by the body even a little, but immediately overpowers and changes it, even if you administer it heated. For their very nature is cold, as is water. Therefore, this too has been rightly said by Aristotle along with many other points: that among warm and cold and dry and moist bodies, some are such in themselves, others only incidentally. For instance, water is cold in itself, but incidentally at times hot. But the heat it acquires from without quickly perishes, while its innate coldness remains. So just as water, even when hot, quenches a flame when poured on it, so also the poppy‑latex, even if you administer it as heated as possible, will chill the heat in living beings and bring on a danger of death. All such drugs, then, when given in small doses and with things capable of curbing the intensity of their cooling, at times provide some benefit to our bodies, as will be said in the works on drugs. For indeed the preparation through cantharides helps those with dropsy quite sufficiently, although as a rule the cantharis ulcerates the bladder; but when it is both curbed by what is mixed with it and administered to a body that contains very much moisture, it empties it through the urine. One must therefore pay very close attention, in all things said to be hot or cold in power, whether they belong to the nature of things capable of nourishing, or whether they merely receive an occasion for alteration and then, being altered according to their own nature, dispose the body in some way; and, thirdly, in addition, whether they are not altered by it at all in any respect. For if it belongs to the class of things that nourish: if it be mastered [by the body], it warms; if it is not mastered, it cools. But if it belongs to those altered only for a short time in respect of quantity, it certainly warms. If it belongs to those not altered at all, it most of all cools.
paragraphs.claude_translation:
Here is my translation of the Ancient Greek text:

But this might perhaps seem to be a point of dispute: that certain foods, when applied externally to the skin, corrode and ulcerate it—such as mustard, preserved fish, garlic, and onions—even though they serve as nourishment when eaten. Yet this actually agrees with our initial premises. For simultaneously: they are changed and altered when digested in the stomach and when converted to blood in the veins; moreover, they do not remain in one place but are divided into many parts and carried everywhere; furthermore, they are mixed with many humors and with other foods taken at the same time; and additionally, their digestion occurs quickly, as does their separation, so that what is suitable is assimilated while what is excessive and sharp in them is expelled through the bowels, urine, and sweat. For all these reasons, what ulcerates externally does not ulcerate when eaten.

Indeed, if even one of the aforementioned conditions existed for them, it would surely be sufficient to keep the external parts unharmed—for instance, if we take first the fact of transformation. For if mustard does not remain such as it was when taken externally, it is clear that you would not expect its power to remain either. And if it is also separated and purified, this is even more the case. The fact that it does not linger in one place would also suffice. For it appears unable to act upon the skin without considerable time. But also its mixing with many other foods is itself no small matter. You would know this if you were to take it alone without other foods—how much distress and irritation it brings to the stomach. And indeed, if you were to mix it with many sweet humors and apply it to the skin, it would cause no harm.

Therefore, since each of the mentioned factors is sufficient by itself to prevent mustard from doing internally what it does externally when applied to the skin, I think this is much more the case when all factors come together. For it is altered when digested, and separated, and purified, and mixed with many other things, and divided in many ways, and carried everywhere, and lingers in no part of the body. That if it remained sharp, it would certainly ulcerate the internal parts too, you may recognize from spontaneous ulcers. For many people often develop what is called cacochymia [bad humor], some from bad foods, others from some corruption and putrefaction in the body itself. And in these cases sometimes something internal is ulcerated; but mostly, because nature expels the superfluities in the body's condition toward the skin, this becomes ulcerated with many continuous ulcers. For cancer, phagedena [spreading ulcer], corrosive herpes, carbuncles, and what are called chironian and telephian ulcers, and countless other types of ulcers are offspring of such cacochymia.

Therefore, none of these things is puzzling, nor why certain drugs that do us no harm externally cause great evil when swallowed; while some often harm when taken internally but often benefit; and some harm not only internally but also externally. To speak generally, nothing naturally acts the same way internally and externally. For neither the foam of a rabid dog, nor the venom of the asp or viper—which are believed to harm even when falling on the skin externally without a wound—have the same power whether merely coming into contact with the skin or being taken internally.

Nor is it worth wondering if the power of certain drugs does not reach to the depths; for not all necessarily have the same strength. And if many things taken internally benefit at this particular time, with this particular quantity, and with this particular mixture, but cause harm when taken at the wrong time, in large amounts, and unmixed, this presents no difficulty for our argument. For this applies to foods, to fire, and similarly to everything that affects the body. We sometimes need moderate flame and derive great benefit from using it, even though excessive flame burns us. Similarly, a moderate drink of cold water benefits, but an excessive one causes extreme harm.

What wonder then if there is some drug so hot in power that if taken in large quantity and given to an empty body, it completely corrodes and burns it, but if little or given with things that check its strength, not only does it not harm but even benefits by warming? For instance, juice—whether Cyrenaic, Median, or Parthian—cannot be taken by itself without pain; but if very little, or with other things at the appropriate time, it greatly benefits. In this way then, whatever warms the body, having taken in it a beginning of change as previously stated, naturally warms it in return; but whatever cools, like poppy juice, is not changed by the body even slightly, but immediately overcomes and changes it, even if you give it warmed. For their nature is cold, just as water is.

Rightly then has Aristotle said this among many other things: that of hot, cold, dry, and wet bodies, some are such in themselves, others accidentally. For instance, water is cold in itself but sometimes accidentally hot. But its acquired heat is quickly lost, while its innate coldness remains. Therefore, just as hot water thrown on flame extinguishes it, so also poppy juice, even if you give it as warm as possible, will cool the heat in animals and bring danger of death.

All such drugs, then, when given in small amounts and with things able to check the violence of their cooling, sometimes provide some use to our bodies, as will be discussed in the works on drugs. For indeed the drug made from cantharides [Spanish fly] sufficiently benefits those with dropsy, although the cantharides generally ulcerate the bladder; but when it is checked by things mixed with it and applied to a body containing very much moisture, it empties this through the urine.

Therefore one must especially pay attention in all things said to be hot or cold in power, whether they are of the nature of things able to nourish, or only take a starting point of alteration and then, being altered according to their own nature, somehow affect the body, and third beyond these, whether they are not altered by it at all in any way. For if they are of the genus of nourishing things, if overcome they warm, but if not overcome they cool; if of things altered to a small degree, they certainly warm; but if of things not altered at all, they especially cool.

paragraphs.content: Προσέχειν δὲ, ὡς εἴρηται, μάλιστα καὶ διορίζεσθαι τὰ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ τῶν κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς, οὐκ ἐπὶ θερμῶν καὶ ψυχρῶν μόνον, ἀλλ’ οὐδὲν ἧττον αὐτῶν ἐφ’ ὑγρῶν τε καὶ ξηρῶν. ἔνια γὰρ τῶν τοιούτων, ξηρὰ ταῖς οὐσίαις ὑπάρχοντα, πολλῷ θερμῷ τακέντα, φαντασίαν ὑγρότητος ἔλαβεν, ὡς χαλκὸς καὶ σίδηρος· ἢ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ μέν ἐστιν ὑγρὰ, καθάπερ ὁ κρύσταλλος, ἀκράτῳ δὲ ψύξει πλησιάζοντα, ξηρὰ φαίνεται. χρὴ τοίνυν τούτων ἁπάντων τὴν κρίσιν οὐχ ἁπλῶς ποιεῖσθαι, καθότι κᾀν τοῖς ἔμπροσθεν ἐλέγομεν, ἀλλὰ μετὰ τοῦ συνεπισκέπτεσθαι, πῶς ἔχει θερμότητος ἢ ψυχρότητος. εἰ μὲν γὰρ, ὀλίγης μετέχοντα θερμότητος, ὅμως καὶ ὑγρὰ φαίνοιτο, διὰ τὴν οἰκείαν φύσιν ἐστὶ τοιαῦτα, κᾂν εἰ μετὰ δαψιλοῦς θερμασίας, ξηρά. τὰ δ’ ἤτοι ῥέοντα μετὰ θερμότητος ζεούσης, ἢ πεπηγότα διὰ ψύξιν ἄκρατον, οὐ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ νομίζειν εἶναι τὰ μὲν ὑγρὰ, τὰ δὲ ξηρά. ταύτῃ τε οὖν διαιρεῖσθαι τὰ καθ’ ἑαυτὰ τῶν κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς, ἀναφέροντά τε πρὸς. αὐτὰ ταῦτα τὴν κρίσιν οὕτω ποιεῖσθαι τῶν δυνάμει θερμῶν, ἢ ψυχρῶν, ἢ ξηρῶν, ἢ ὑγρῶν. οὐ γὰρ πρὸς τὸ κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς, ἀλλὰ πρὸς τὸ καθ’ ἑαυτὸ χρὴ κρίνεσθαι τὸ δυνάμει. κοινὴ δ’ ἐπὶ πάντων ἡ κρίσις καὶ μία τὸ τάχος τῆς ἀλλοιώσεως. ὁμωνύμως δὲ λεγομένου τοῦ θερμοῦ, καὶ ψυχροῦ, καὶ ξηροῦ, καὶ ὑγροῦ· τὰ μὲν γὰρ κατ’ ἐπικράτησιν οὕτως ὀνομάζεται, τὰ δ’ ὡς ἄκραν ἔχοντα ἧς παρονομάζεται ποιότητος· εἰς ὁπότερον αὐτῶν ἑτοίμως μεθίσταται τὸ κρινόμενον, ἔσται δυνάμει τοιοῦτο. ἔλαιον μὲν γάρ ἐστι δυνάμει θερμὸν, ὅτι ῥᾳδίως φλὸξ γίνεται. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ ῥητίνη, καὶ ἄσφαλτος, καὶ πίττα. οἶνος δὲ, διότι ῥᾳδίως αἷμα γίνεται. κατὰ ταὐτὰ δὲ καὶ μέλι, καὶ κρέας, καὶ γάλα. ταυτὶ μὲν οὖν, ὅλαις ἀλλοιούμενα ταῖς οὐσίαις, τροφαὶ τῶν ἀλλοιούντων εἰσί. τὰ δὲ κατὰ μίαν ἡντιναοῦν ποιότητα τὴν ἀλλοίωσιν ἴσχοντά τε καὶ τρεπόμενα, φάρμακα μόνον, ὥσπερ γε καὶ ὅσα ταῖς ὅλαις ἑαυτῶν οὐσίαις ἄτρεπτα μένοντα διατίθησι τὸ σῶμα, φάρμακα μέν ἐστι καὶ ταῦτα· χαλεπὰ δὲ καὶ φθαρτικὰ τῆς τοῦ ζώου φύσεως· ὅθεν περ, οἶμαι, καὶ τὸ γένος αὐτῶν ἅπαν ὀνομάζεται δηλητήριον. οὐ γὰρ δὴ διὰ τοῦτό γε λεκτέον οὐκ εἶναι τῷ γένει δηλητήρια τὰ τοιαῦτα, διότι παντελῶς ἐλάχιστα προσαχθέντα βλάβην οὐδὲ μίαν αἰσθητὴν ἐπιφέρει. οὕτω γὰρ ἂν οὐδὲ τὸ πῦρ εἴη θερμὸν, οὐδ’ ἡ χιὼν ψυχρά· ὡς καὶ τούτων γε παντάπασι τὰ σμικρὰ σαφὲς οὐδὲν ἀποτελεῖ περὶ τοῖς σώμασιν ἡμῶν πάθος. σπινθῆρος γὰρ ἑνὸς ἑκατοστὸν μέρος ἔστι μὲν πάντως τῷ γένει πῦρ, ἀλλ’ οὐ μόνον οὐκ ἂν ἡμᾶς καύσειεν ἢ θερμῄνειεν, ἀλλ’ οὐδ’ ἄν αἴσθησίν τινα παράσχοι προσπεσόν. οὕτω δὲ καὶ τὸ τῆς ψυχρᾶς ῥανίδος ἑκατοστὸν μέρος οὐ μόνον οὐδὲν ἂν βλάψειεν ἢ ψύξειεν, ἀλλ’ οὐδ’ ἂν αἴσθησίν τινα παράσχοι. μὴ τοίνυν οὕτως μηδὲ τὰ δηλητήρια κρίνειν, ἀλλὰ τῇ τῆς ὅλης φύσεως ἐναντιώσει, τὴν δ’ ἐναντίωσιν ἐκ τῆς ἐμμέσου κρίνειν μεταβολῆς. οἷον εὐθέως ἀπὸ τῶν στοιχείων οὔθ’ ὕδωρ εἰς πῦρ, οὔτε πῦρ εἰς ὕδωρ μεταβάλλειν πέφυκεν, ἀλλ’ εἰς ἀέρα μὲν ἄμφω, ἐκεῖνος δ’ εἰς ἑκάτερα, εἰς ἄλληλα δὲ ταῦτ’ οὐδαμῶς. ἄμεσος μὲν οὖν ἡ εἰς ἀέρα μεταβολὴ τοῦ ὕδατος· ὡσαύτως δὲ καὶ τοῦ πυρός. οὐκ ἄμεσον δὲ ἡ πυρὸς καὶ ὕδατος εἰς ἄλληλα ταῦτ’ οὖν ἀλλήλοις ἐναντία ἐστὶ καὶ πολέμια. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν τρόπον καὶ ὀπὸς μήκωνος ἀνθρωπείῳ σώματι τελέως ἐστὶν ἐναντίος, οὐδὲν εἰς αὐτὸ οὔτε κατὰ μίαν ποιότητα δρᾶσαι δυνάμενον, οὔτε πολὺ δὴ μᾶλλον ἔτι καθ’ ὅλην τὴν οὐσίαν. ἓν μὲν δὴ τοῦτο γένος τῶν δηλητηρίων. ἕτερον δὲ τῶν ἀφορμὴν μέν τινα μεταβολῆς λαμβανόντων ἐκ τῆς ἐν ἡμῖν θερμασίας, εἰς πολυειδεῖς δ’ ἐντεῦθεν ἐκτρεπομένων ἀλλοιώσεις, ὑφ’ ὧν διαφθείρεσθαι τὴν φύσιν ἡμῶν συμβαίνει. πάντα γὰρ τὰ τοιαῦτα τῷ γένει δηλητήρια, κᾂν διὰ σμικρότητά ποτε μηδὲν αἰσθητὸν ἀπεργάζηται. τὰ μὲν δὴ διαβιβρώσκοντα καὶ σήποντα καὶ τήκοντα τὴν τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν φύσιν εἰκότως ὀνομάζεται δυνάμει θερμά· τὰ δ’ αὖ ψύχοντα καὶ ναρκοῦντα ψυχρά. τὰ μὲν οὖν πρότερα παράλογον οὐδὲν οὔτε αὐτὰ πάσχειν, οὔτε τοῖς σώμασιν ἡμῶν ἐναπεργάζεσθαι δοκεῖ. θερμῷ γὰρ σώματι πλησιάσαντα, καί τινα ῥοπὴν ἀλλοιώσεως ἐντεῦθεν λαβόντα, τὰ μὲν εἰς ἐσχάτην ἀφικνεῖται θερμότητα, τὰ δ’ εἰς σηπεδόνα. διατίθησιν οὖν εἰκότως καὶ τὰ τῶν ζώων σώματα κατὰ τὴν ἑαυτῶν διάθεσιν. ὅσα δὲ ψύχει τὸ σῶμα, κᾂν θερμῄνας αὐτὰ προσενέγκῃς, ἀπορίαν οὐ σμικρὰν ἐπιφέρει, τίνος ποτὲ φύσεώς ἐστιν. εἰ γὰρ ἅπαξ ἐνεργείᾳ θερμὰ γέγονε, τί οὐ θερμαίνει τὸ ζῶον; ἢ εἰ μήπω τεθέρμανται, πῶς φαίνεται θερμά; λύσις δὲ τῆς ἀπορίας, εἰ διορισθείη τὸ καθ’ αὑτὸ ψυχρὸν τοῦ κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς, ὡς Ἀριστοτέλης ἐδίδαξεν. ἀπόλλυται γὰρ ἐν τάχει τῶν κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς θερμῶν ἡ ἐπίκτητος διάθεσις, ὥστ’ εἰς τὴν ἀρχαίαν αὐτὰ φύσιν ἐπανέρχεσθαι ῥᾳδίως. ἐν δὲ τῷ πλησιάζειν ἡμῖν τὰ φύσει μὲν ψυχρὰ, κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς δὲ θερμὰ, δύο ταῦτ’ ἐξ ἀνάγκης γίνεται· τὸ μὲν ἐπίκτητον αὐτῶν ἀπόλλυται θερμὸν, ἡ δ’ οἰκεία κρᾶσις, οὐδὲν ὑπὸ τῆς ἡμετέρας πάσχουσα, μένει ψυχρά, καὶ τί θαυμαστὸν, εἰ μήκωνος ὀπὸς, ἢ μανδραγόρας, ἢ κώνειον, ἤ τι τῶν τοιούτων, εἶ καὶ θερμανθέντα προσενεχθείης, μικρὸν ὕστερον γίνεται ψυχρά; πτισσάνης, καὶ γάλακτος, καὶ χόνδρου, καὶ ἄρτου, τὸ αὐτὸ τοῦτο πασχόντων, ἐπειδὰν εἰς ἄῤῥωστον ἐμπεσόντα γαστέρα μὴ κρατηθῇ πρὸς αὐτῆς· ἐμεῖται γοῦν πολλάκις ἱκανῶς ψυχρά. καὶ τό γε τούτων μεῖζον, ὃ δὴ καὶ Ἱπποκράτης ἐπεσημῄνατο· καίτοι χυμὸς ὂν ἤδη τὸ φλέγμα, κᾀκ τῶν σιτίων τῶν μὴ πεφθέντων πολλάκις ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ γεννώμενος, ὅμως ψυχρὸν ἁπτομένοις φαίνεται, οὐ μόνον ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ συστὰν, ἀλλὰ κᾀκ τῶν φλεβῶν αὐτῶν ὑπό τινος τῶν καθαιρόντων φαρμάκων ἑλχθέν. καί τοί γε γλισχρότατόν ἐστι σφόδρα, καὶ βιαίως ἄγεται, ἀλλ’ ὅμως οὐδ’ ἡ βία τῆς ὁλκῆς ἐκθερμαίνειν αὐτὸ δύναται. τί οὖν θαυμαστὸν, εἰ καὶ τὸ μηκώνειον, οὕτως ἐναντίον ἡμῶν τῇ φύσει φάρμακον, ἀποψύχεται μὲν αὐτίκα μάλα, κᾂν θερμὸν ποθῇ, συγκαταψύχει δ’ ἑαυτῷ τὸ σῶμα. τὴν γὰρ ἐπίκτητον οὐ φυλάττει θερμασίαν, ὅτι φύσει ψυχρὸν ἦν· τῷ δὲ μηδ’ ἀλλοιοῦσθαι τὴν οὐσίαν αὐτοῦ πρὸς ἡμῶν, ἀλλὰ μᾶλλον ἀλλοιοῦν τε καὶ μεταβάλλειν ἡμᾶς, οὔτε θερμαίνεταί τι πρὸς ἡμῶν, αὐτό τε διατίθησιν ἡμᾶς καθ’ αὑτό· ψυχρὸν οὖν ὑπάρχον φύσει, ψύχει δήπου καὶ ἡμᾶς. οὐκοῦν οὐκέτ’ ἄπορον οὐδὲν ὑπόλοιπον ἐν τῷ λόγῳ. καὶ γὰρ δὴ καὶ ὅτι τούτων ἁπάντων τῶν φύσει ψυχρῶν ὅ τι ἂν ἐπὶ πλέον ἐκθερμῄνης, ἐξίσταται τῆς ἰδίας φύσεως, πρὸς τῷ μηδὲν ἄπορον ἔχειν, ἔτι καὶ μαρτυρεῖ τοῖς εἰρημένοις. ὡς γὰρ καὶ ἡ σαλαμάνδρα μέχρι μέν τινος ὑπὸ πυρὸς οὐδὲν πάσχει, κατακαίεται δ’, εἰ πλείονι χρόνῳ τῷ πυρὶ πλησιάσειεν, οὕτω καὶ ὁ μανδραγόρας, καὶ κώνειον, καὶ ψύλλιον, ἐπὶ βραχὺ μὲν ὁμιλήσαντα τῷ πυρὶ, τὴν οἰκείαν ἔτι διαφυλάττει κρᾶσιν, ἐπὶ πλέον δὲ θερμανθέντα, διαφθείρεται παραχρῆμα, καὶ δρᾷν οὐκέτι οὐδὲν ὧν πρότερον ἐπεφύκει δύναται. τῶν μὲν δὴ τοιούτων ἁπάντων ἡ φύσις ἐναντιωτάτη τοῖς ἀνθρώποις ἐστί· φύσιν δ’ ὅταν εἴπω, τὴν ὅλην οὐσίαν τε καὶ κρᾶσιν λέγω, τὴν ἐκ τῶν πρώτων στοιχείων, θερμοῦ καὶ ψυχροῦ, καὶ ξηροῦ καὶ ὑγροῦ· τῶν δὲ τάχιστα τρεφόντων οἰκειοτάτη. τὰ δ’ ἄλλα πάντα μεταξὺ τούτων ἐστί· τὰ μὲν μᾶλλον, τὰ δ’ ἧττον δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ὑπὸ τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν δυνάμενα. καστόριον μὲν γὰρ καὶ πέπερι δρᾷν μᾶλλον ἢ πάσχειν ὑπὸ τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν δυνάμενα· οἶνος δὲ καὶ μέλι καὶ πτισσάνη πάσχειν μᾶλλον ἢ δρᾷν. ἅπαντα οὖν ταῦτα καὶ πάσχει τι καὶ δρᾷ περὶ τὸ σῶμα. καθ’ ὅλου γὰρ ἐπειδὰν εἰς ταὐτὸ ἀλλήλοις ἥκοντα διαμάχηταί τε καὶ στασιάζῃ πρὸς ἄλληλα περὶ τῆς ἀλλοιώσεως ἐν χρόνῳ πλείονι, δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν ἑκάτερον αὐτῶν ἀναγκαῖόν ἐστιν. ἴσως δὲ, κᾂν μὴ πολλῷ πάνυ χρόνῳ γίγνηται τοῦτο, δρᾷ μὲν ἔτι καὶ τότε τὸ νικώμενον εἰς τὸ κρατοῦν, ἀλλ’ οὕτω σμικρὸν, ὡς λανθάνειν τὴν αἴσθησιν. οὐδὲ γὰρ ὁ τμητικώτατος σίδηρος εἰ τὸν μαλακώτατον τέμνει κηρὸν δι’ ὅλης ἡμέρας καὶ νυκτὸς, ἀδύνατον αὐτῷ μὴ οὐκ ἀμβλὺν γενέσθαι σαφῶς. οὕτω δή που κᾀκεῖνο καλῶς εἰρῆσθαι δοκεῖ, Πέτρην κοιλαίνει ῥανὶς ὕδατος ἐνδελεχείῃ. καὶ γὰρ καὶ φαίνεται γινόμενον οὕτως. ἀλλ’ ἐπὶ μὲν μιᾶς ἢ καὶ δευτέρας προσβολῆς οὐδὲν οὔπω σαφὲς ἐν τοῖς τοιούτοις ἰδεῖν ἐστιν. ὅθεν, οἶμαι, καὶ τὸ μηδ’ ὅλως πάσχειν ἔνια πρὸς τῶν ὁμιλούντων ἐδοξάσθη τισί· καὶ συγχωρητέον γε τοῖς οὕτω λέγουσι. πολλάκις δὲ καὶ αὐτοὺς ἡμᾶς ὁμοίως ἐκείνοις λεκτέον ἐστὶ τὰ πολλά· πλὴν εἴ ποτε μέχρι τῆς ἐσχάτης ἀκριβείας ἀνάγοιμεν τὸν λόγον, ὥσπερ ἐν τῷ παρόντι ποιοῦμεν. οὕτως οὖν καὶ τὸ τῆς ἀειπαθείας δόγμα, τῷ λόγῳ μὲν αὐτῷ μόνῳ σκοποῦσιν, ἰσχυρὰν ἔχει τὴν ἀπόδειξιν. οὐ μὴν χρεία γέ τίς ἐστιν αὐτοῦ πρὸς τὰς κατὰ μέρος πράξεις. ἂν γὰρ οὕτω μικρά τινα περὶ ἡμᾶς ᾖ πάθη διὰ παντὸς, ὡς μηδεμίαν αἰσθητὴν καὶ σαφῆ βλάβην ἐνεργείας ἐργάζεσθαι μηδεμιᾶς, εὐκαταφρόνητα δήπουθέν ἐστι, καὶ τῷ μηδὲν εἶναι φάσκοντι τὰ τοιαῦτα συγχωρητέον. οὕτως οὖν ἔχει κᾀπὶ τῶν τρεφόντων, ὀλίγου δεῖν, ἁπάντων. ἐργάζεται μὲν γάρ τι καὶ ταῦτα περὶ τὸ σῶμα τῶν ἀνθρώπων, ἀλλ’ οὐκ αἰσθητὸν, οὐδὲ σαφές τι καθάπαξ. ἡ μέντοι πολυχρόνιος αὐτῶν προσφορὰ μεγάλως ἀλλοιοῖ καὶ μεταβάλλει σαφῶς ἤδη τὰ σώματα. ἔνια μέν γε καὶ κατὰ τὴν πρώτην χρῆσιν εὐθὺς ἐναργῶς ἐνδείκνυται τὴν ἀλλοίῳσιν, οἶον καὶ ἡ θριδακίνη, τοὺς μὲν ἐγκαιομένους τὴν γαστέρα σαφῶς ἐμψύχουσά τε καὶ ἀδίψους ἐργαζομένη, τοὺς δὲ κατεψυγμένους ἐναργῶς βλάπτουσα. συντελεῖ δ’ οὐ σμικρὰ καὶ τοῖς ὕπνοις, οὐ κατ’ ἄλλον τινὰ λόγον, ἀλλ’ ὅτι ψυχρά τέ ἐστι καὶ ὑγρὰ τὴν κρᾶσιν· ἀλλ’ οὕτως ὑγρὰ καὶ ψυχρὰ πρὸς ἄνθρωπόν τε καὶ τἄλλ’, ὅσα τρέφειν πέφυκεν, ὡς καὶ τὰ ξύλα τὰ χλωρὰ πρὸς τὸ πῦρ. ὥστ’ εὐλόγως ἄμφω τοῖς τοιούτοις ἐδέσμασιν ὑπάρχει, τό θ’ ὡς φαρμάκοις διατιθέναι τὰ σώμαθ’ ἡμῶν, καὶ τὸ τρέφειν, παρ’ ὅλον μὲν τὸν χρόνον τῆς πέψεως, ὡς φαρμάκοις· ἡνίκα δ’ ἤδη τρέφει τε καὶ τελέως ὁμοιοῦται, τότ’ οὐκέτ’ οὐδὲν ἡμᾶς ἀντιδρῶντα, τὴν ἔμφυτον αὔξει θερμασίαν, ὡς καὶ πρόσθεν εἴρηται. κοινὸν γὰρ ἤδη τῶν τρεφόντων ἁπάντων ἐστὶ, καὶ οὐ χρὴ θαυμάζειν, εἴ τι, πρὶν μὲν ἐξομοιοῦσθαι καὶ τρέφειν, ἔτι πεττόμενον ἔψυχεν, ἐξομοιωθὲν δὲ καὶ θρέψαν, ἐθέρμῃνε, μεμνημένους ἀεὶ τοῦ τῶν χλωρῶν ξύλων παραδείγματος. ὥστε καὶ ἡ χρεία τῶν τοιούτων ἁπάντων διττὴ τοῖς ἰατροῖς ἐστι, καὶ ὡς σιτίων, καὶ ὡς φαρμάκων. φέρε γὰρ ὑπηλλάχθαι τινὶ τὴν ἀρίστην ἐν τῇ γαστρὶ κρᾶσιν ἐπὶ τὸ θερμότερον. οὗτος, ἄχρι μὲν οὗ πέττει τὴν θριδακίνην, ἐμψυχθήσεται καὶ συμμετρίαν κτήσεται κράσεως· ἐπειδὰν δ’ ἐξ αὐτῆς ἤδη τρέφηται, τὴν οὐσίαν αὐξήσει τῆς ἐμφύτου θερμασίας. ἐν τούτῳ δὴ καὶ μάλιστα δοκοῦσί μοι παραλογίζεσθαι σφᾶς αὐτοὺς οἱ πολλοὶ τῶν νεωτέρων ἰατρῶν, ἀγνοοῦντες, ὡς ἐνίοτε μὲν ἡ ποιότης ἐπιτείνεται τῆς ἐν ἡμῖν θερμασίας, ἐνίοτε δ’ ἡ οὐσία παραύξεται, καὶ ὡς ἑκατέρως οἱ παλαιοὶ θερμότερον γεγονέναι τὸ ζῶόν φασι. καὶ γὰρ καὶ γίνεται θερμότερον, ἄντ’ ἐπιτείνῃς αὐτοῦ τὴν θερμασίαν, ἄντ’ αὐξήσῃς τὴν οὐσίαν, ἐν ᾗ πρώτῃ περιέχεται. φέρε γὰρ εἶναι τὸ αἷμα τὸ ἐν τῷ σώματι τοῦ ζώου καθ’ αὑτὸ θερμὸν, ἢ, νὴ Δία, εἰ βούλει τὴν ξανθὴν χολὴν, ἅπαντα δὲ τἄλλα κατὰ συμβεβηκὸς ὑπάρχειν θερμὰ τῷ τούτων μετέχειν. ἆρ’ οὐκ ἀναγκαῖον ἔσται, διττῶς γίνεσθαι θερμότερον τὸ ζῶον, ἤτοι τῷ πλείονας ἐπικτήσασθαι χυμοὺς θερμοὺς, ἢ τῷ θερμοτέρους ἔχειν, ἢ πρότερον; ἐμοὶ μὲν καὶ πάνυ φαίνεται. κατὰ δὲ τὸν αὐτὸν, οἶμαι, τρόπον καὶ ψυχρότερον ἔσται διττῶς, ἢ τῷ πλείους ὑποτραφῆναι τοὺς ψυχροὺς χυμοὺς, οἶον τὸ φλέγμα καὶ τὴν μέλαιναν χολὴν, ἢ τῷ, τῆς αὐτῶν ἁπάντων μενούσης συμμετρίας, ὑπαλλαχθῆναι μόνην τὴν ποιότητα. τί δὴ οὖν θαυμαστὸν, ἄχρι μὲν ἂν πέπτηται τὸ ψυχρὸν τῇ φύσει σιτίον, οἶον ἀνδράχνη τε καὶ θριδακίνη, ψυχρᾶς ποιότητος ἀναπίμπλασθαι τὸ σῶμα, πεφθέντων δ’ ἀκριβῶς καὶ γενομένων αἷμα χρηστὸν, θερμότερον αὖθις ἑαυτοῦ γίνεσθαι τὸ σῶμα τῇ τοῦ θερμοῦ χυμοῦ γενέσει; καὶ μὴν εἰ μηδὲν τούτων μήτ’ ἀδύνατόν ἐστι, μήτε θαυμαστὸν ἔτι, παυσάσθωσαν οἱ μὴ συγχωροῦντες, ἓν καὶ ταὐτὸ ἔδεσμα καὶ τὴν ὡς τροφῆς καὶ τὴν ὡς φαρμάκου χρείαν τῷ ζώῳ παρέχειν. ὡς γὰρ, εἰ καὶ μηδ’ ὅλως ἐπέφθη, διὰ παντὸς ἂν ἐφυλάχθη φάρμακον, οὕτω πεφθὲν ἄμφω γίνεται. φέρε γὰρ μηδ’ ὅλως πεφθῆναι τὴν θριδακίνην, ἢ, νὴ Δία, τὸν χυλὸν αὐτῆς, ἐπειδὴ καὶ παραπλήσια τῷ τοῦ μήκωνος ὀπῷ δρᾷ εἰς τὸν ἄνθρωπον, εἰ πάμπολυς ληφθείη, ἆρ’ οὖν φάρμακον ἔσται τηνικαῦτα μόνον, ἄλλο δ’ οὐδέν; οὐκ οἶμαί τινα περί γε τούτου ἀμφισβητήσειν. ὥστ’ ἔχει πάντως καὶ τὴν τοῦ φαρμάκου δύναμιν ἡ θριδακίνη. ἀλλὰ μὴν ἔσχε καὶ τὴν τῆς τροφῆς· ἔθρεψε γὰρ πολλάκις. ὥστ’ ἀμφοτέρας μὲν ἅμα τὰς δυνάμεις ἐν ἑαυτῇ περιέχει, δείκνυσι δ’ οὐχ ὁμοίως ἀμφοτέρας, ἀλλ’ ἐπειδὰν μὲν αὐτὴ πλέον ἐνεργῇ περὶ τὸν ἄνθρωπον ἢ πάσχῃ, τὴν ὡς φαρμάκου μᾶλλον ἐπιδείκνυται δύναμιν· ἐπειδὰν δὲ πάσχῃ πλέον, ἢ ποιῇ, τὴν ὡς σιτίου. καὶ θαυμαστὸν οὐδὲν, εἰ τῇ θριδακίνῃ καὶ δρᾷν καὶ πάσχειν συμβέβηκεν, ὅπου γε καὶ τῷ ξίφει, καθότι καὶ μικρὸν ἔμπροσθεν ἐλέγομεν, μὴ μόνον δρᾶν εἰς τὸν κηρὸν, ἀλλὰ καὶ πάσχειν ὑπάρχει. τῷ δ’ εἶναι πολὺ πλέον ὃ πέφυκε δρᾷν, ἢ πάσχειν, λανθάνει θάτερον. ἀλλ’ εἰ σκληρότατον αὐτῷ παραβάλλοις σίδηρον, ἔμπαλίν σοι φανεῖται πάσχειν μᾶλλον, ἢ δρᾷν, καίτοι δρᾷ μέν τι καὶ τότε, παρορᾶται δ’ ἡ δύναμις αὐτοῦ διὰ σμικρότητα. θαῤῥοῦντες οὖν ἐπὶ πάντων μὲν ἁπλῶς ἀποφαινόμεθα τῶν σιτίων, ὡς οὐ μόνον πάσχειν ὑπὸ τοῦ σώματος ἡμῶν, ἀλλὰ καὶ δρᾷν εἰς αὐτὸ πέφυκεν· ἤδη δὲ καὶ περί τινων, οἷς ἐναργῶς καὶ σαφῶς ὑπάρχει τὸ δρᾷν, ὡς οὐ σιτία μόνον ἐστὶν, ἀλλὰ καὶ φάρμακα. θριδακίνη μὲν οὖν καὶ τροφὴ καὶ φάρμακον ψυχρόν· εὔζωμον δὲ καὶ τροφὴ καὶ φάρμακον θερμόν. εἰ δὲ καὶ καστόριον ἐν τῷ χρόνῳ πέττεται, εἴη ἂν καὶ τοῦτο τροφή τε ἅμα καὶ φάρμακον θερμόν. οὕτω δὲ καὶ νάπυ, καὶ πέπερι, καὶ τῶν βοτανῶν ἄνηθόν τε καὶ πήγανον, ὀρίγανόν τε καὶ γλήχων, καὶ καλαμίνθη; καὶ θύμβρα, καὶ θύμος. πάντα γὰρ ταῦτα καὶ τροφαὶ καὶ φάρμακα θερμά. πρὶν γὰρ εἰς αἷμα μεταβαλεῖν, ἔτι γε πεττόμενα, φάρμακα· μεταβληθέντα δὲ, οὐκ Pay closest attention, as I said, to distinguishing intrinsic properties from incidental ones—not only with respect to hot and cold, but no less for wet and dry. For some things of this sort, being dry in their substances, when melted by much heat take on the appearance of moisture, like bronze and iron; or else some are wet in themselves, like crystal, but when brought near untempered cold, they seem dry. Therefore one must not make judgments about all these things simply, as I remarked earlier, but always with the further scrutiny of how they stand in respect of heat or cold. For if something, though sharing in only a little heat, nevertheless still appears wet, it is such by its own nature; and if, even with abundant heating, it remains dry, it is likewise so by nature. Things that either flow with boiling heat, or are congealed by unmitigated cold, are not to be taken as wet or dry in themselves.

In this way, then, separate what is intrinsic from what is incidental, and refer your judgment to the things themselves, thus determining which are potentially hot, or cold, or dry, or wet. For potentiality should be judged not by what is incidental, but by what is intrinsic. And the common, single criterion for all is the speed of alteration. Since “hot,” “cold,” “dry,” and “wet” are said homonymously [with more than one related sense], some are so named by predominance, others because they possess the extreme of the quality from which they are named; that to which the thing under judgment readily passes, that is what it will be potentially. Thus oil is potentially hot because it easily becomes flame; the same holds for resin, asphalt, and pitch. Wine is [potentially hot] because it easily becomes blood; likewise honey, meat, and milk. These things, since they are altered in respect of their whole substances, are the food of the things that alter them. But those which both constrain and undergo alteration according to a single specific quality are only drugs; and likewise those that, remaining unchangeable in their whole substances, dispose the body—these too are drugs, but harsh and destructive to the nature of the living creature; whence, I think, their entire class is called “poison” [dēlētērion]. We must not say that such things are not, by their class, poisons simply because, when administered in an extremely small amount, they cause no perceptible harm. For then fire would not be hot, nor snow cold, since exceedingly small portions of these produce no clear effect on our bodies. For a hundredth part of a spark is, by its kind, certainly fire, yet not only would it not burn or warm us, it would not even cause any sensation when it falls on us. Likewise, a hundredth part of a drop of cold liquid would not only fail to harm or chill, it would not even produce any sensation. Do not, then, judge poisons in this way, but by their contrariety to the entire nature [of the living being], and judge this contrariety from the change that occurs through an intermediate [state]. For example, directly from the elements, neither does water change into fire, nor fire into water; rather both pass into air, and that [air] into either of the two; but into each other—not at all. The change of water into air is direct; likewise for fire. But the change of fire into water, and of water into fire, is not direct. Thus these are opposite and hostile to one another.

In the same way, the juice of the poppy [opium] is utterly opposed to the human body: it cannot act upon it in any way, either according to a single quality or, much less, according to its whole substance. This is one class of poisons. Another is that which takes from our internal heat some starting-point for change, and from there is diverted into multiform alterations, through which our nature comes to be destroyed. All such things are, by their kind, poisons—even if at times, because of their smallness, they effect nothing perceptible. Those that corrode, rot, and liquefy the nature of our body are reasonably called potentially hot; those that chill and benumb are [potentially] cold. There is nothing puzzling about the former, whether in what they themselves undergo or in what they produce in our bodies. Having approached a warm body and taken from it some inclination toward alteration, some of them arrive at extreme heat, others at putrefaction. Accordingly, they dispose the bodies of animals in conformity with their own disposition. But those that cool the body—even if you bring them warmed—cause no small perplexity as to what their nature is. For if once they have become actively hot, why do they not warm the living creature? And if they are not yet warmed, how do they appear warm? The solution to the puzzle comes if one distinguishes what is cold in itself from what is cold incidentally, as Aristotle taught. The acquired disposition of things that are hot incidentally perishes quickly, so that they readily return to their original nature. One must pay attention, as has been said, and especially distinguish things that exist in themselves from those that exist accidentally, not only in the case of hot and cold things, but no less in the case of moist and dry things. For some such things, being dry in their substances, when melted by much heat, take on an appearance of moisture, like bronze and iron; or they are moist in themselves, like ice, but when approaching unmixed cold, they appear dry. Therefore, one must not make judgments about all these things simply, as we were saying earlier, but along with considering how they stand in relation to heat or cold. For if things appear moist while partaking of little heat, they are such by their own nature; and if they appear dry despite abundant heat, [they are dry by nature]. But things either flowing with boiling heat or congealed through unmixed cold should not be considered moist or dry in themselves. In this way, then, one should distinguish things that exist in themselves from those that exist accidentally, and referring to these very things, thus make judgments about things potentially hot, cold, dry, or moist. For one must judge what is potential not in relation to the accidental, but in relation to what exists in itself.

The common and single criterion for all is the speed of alteration. Since "hot," "cold," "dry," and "moist" are spoken of homonymously—for some things are named thus by predominance, others as having the extreme of the quality from which they are named—into whichever of these the thing being judged readily changes, it will be potentially of that nature. For oil is potentially hot because it easily becomes flame. Similarly also resin, asphalt, and pitch. Wine [is potentially hot] because it easily becomes blood. Similarly also honey, meat, and milk. These things, then, being altered in their whole substances, become nourishment for the things that alter them. But things that undergo alteration and change in any single quality are medicines only, just as things that remain unchanged in their whole substances while affecting the body are also medicines; but these are harsh and destructive to the animal's nature. Hence, I think, their entire class is called poisonous.

For one should not say that such things are not poisonous by nature just because when administered in extremely small amounts they cause no perceptible harm. For in this way neither would fire be hot nor snow cold; for extremely small amounts of these too produce no clear effect on our bodies. For a hundredth part of a single spark is certainly fire by nature, but it would not only not burn or warm us, but would not even provide any sensation when it strikes us. Similarly, a hundredth part of a cold droplet would not only cause no harm or cooling, but would not even provide any sensation. Therefore, one should not judge poisons in this way either, but by their opposition to the whole nature, and judge the opposition from intermediate change.

For example, from the elements themselves, neither water naturally changes into fire nor fire into water, but both into air, and that into each of them, but these in no way into each other. The change of water into air is immediate; likewise that of fire. But the change of fire and water into each other is not immediate. These, therefore, are opposite and hostile to each other. In the same way, poppy juice is completely opposite to the human body, being unable to act upon it either in any single quality or much less in its whole substance. This, then, is one class of poisons. Another consists of those that take some starting point of change from the heat within us, but from there turn to manifold alterations, by which our nature happens to be destroyed. For all such things are poisons by nature, even if sometimes due to their small amount they produce no perceptible effect.

Things that corrode, putrefy, and dissolve our body's nature are reasonably called potentially hot; those that cool and numb, cold. The former seem to undergo and produce in our bodies nothing contrary to reason. For approaching a hot body and taking from it some impulse toward alteration, some reach extreme heat, others putrefaction. They therefore reasonably affect animals' bodies according to their own condition. But things that cool the body, even if you apply them heated, create no small difficulty about what their nature might be. For if they have once become actually hot, why do they not warm the animal? Or if they are not yet warmed, how do they appear hot?

The solution to this difficulty is if one distinguishes what is cold in itself from what is accidentally cold, as Aristotle taught. For the acquired condition of accidentally hot things is quickly destroyed, so that they easily return to their original nature. When things naturally cold but accidentally hot approach us, two things necessarily happen: their acquired heat is destroyed, and their own mixture, suffering nothing from ours, remains cold. And what is surprising if poppy juice, mandrake, hemlock, or something of the sort, even if you apply them heated, become cold shortly after? The same thing happens to barley gruel, milk, wheat porridge, and bread when they fall into a weak stomach and are not mastered by it; for they are often vomited quite cold. And what is greater than this, which Hippocrates also noted: although phlegm is already a humor, often generated in the stomach from undigested foods, nevertheless it feels cold to the touch, not only when collected in the stomach, but even when drawn from the veins themselves by some purging medicine. And although it is extremely viscous and is drawn out violently, nevertheless not even the violence of the extraction can warm it.

What is surprising, then, if poppy juice, a medicine so contrary to our nature, immediately cools down even if drunk hot, and cools the body along with itself? For it does not preserve its acquired heat because it was naturally cold; and by its substance not being altered by us, but rather altering and changing us, it is neither warmed by us, and it affects us according to itself; being naturally cold, it certainly cools us too. Therefore, nothing difficult remains in the argument. For indeed, the fact that all these naturally cold things, if you heat them excessively, depart from their own nature, not only presents no difficulty, but even testifies to what has been said. For just as the salamander suffers nothing from fire up to a point, but is burned if it approaches fire for a longer time, so also mandrake, hemlock, and fleawort, having brief contact with fire, still preserve their own mixture, but when heated more, are immediately destroyed and can no longer do any of what they naturally could before.

The nature of all such things is most contrary to humans; and when I say nature, I mean the whole substance and mixture from the primary elements, hot and cold, dry and moist; while that of things that nourish most quickly is most akin. All other things are between these, some more, others less able to act upon and be affected by our body. For castoreum and pepper are able to act upon rather than be affected by our body; while wine, honey, and barley gruel [are able] to be affected rather than to act. All these things, therefore, both are affected by and act upon the body. For generally, when things come together and fight and contend with each other about alteration over a longer time, it is necessary for each of them to act and be affected. Perhaps even if this doesn't happen over a very long time, the thing being overcome still acts upon the victor, but so slightly as to escape sensation. For even the sharpest iron, if it cuts the softest wax throughout day and night, cannot avoid becoming clearly blunt. Thus indeed that saying seems well put: "A drop of water hollows rock with persistence." For this is seen to happen thus. But in one or two impacts, nothing clear can yet be seen in such cases.

Hence, I think, some have believed that certain things are not affected at all by what they encounter; and we must concede to those who speak thus. Often we ourselves must speak similarly to them about most things, except when we might carry the argument to ultimate precision, as we are doing at present. Thus the doctrine of constant affection [aeipatheias], for those examining it by reason alone, has strong demonstration. However, there is no use for it in particular practices. For if there are always such small affections about us as to produce no perceptible and clear harm to any function, they are certainly contemptible, and we must concede to one who says such things are nothing.

This is how it is with almost all nourishing things. For these too produce some effect on human bodies, but nothing perceptible or clearly evident at once. However, their prolonged administration greatly alters and clearly changes bodies. Some indeed immediately show alteration clearly even at first use, like lettuce, which clearly cools those with burning stomachs and makes them thirstless, but clearly harms those who are chilled. But things that are either flowing with boiling heat, or are solidified by extreme cold, one must not consider to be, in the one case, essentially wet, or in the other, essentially dry. By this method, then, one should separate the essential from the accidental, and by referring to these very principles, one should thus make a judgment of things that are potentially hot, or cold, or dry, or wet.
